      $('rating_details').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });
      $('rating_details').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

      <div id="description" class="readable stacked" style="right:0">

<span id="freeTextContainer12631080021433960449">A werewolf fighting for her humanity.<br />A gladiator fighting for love.<br />A blind mage, a human sacrifice and a big, buff fairy, all fighting off demons to save the world.<br /><br />Twelve writers. Twelve worlds. Twelve warriors.<br /><br />WARRIOR is an anthology of twelve exciting science-fiction and fantasy short stories, bursting with unstoppable characters that happen to identify within the LGBTQI</span>
  <span id="freeText12631080021433960449" style="display:none">A werewolf fighting for her humanity.<br />A gladiator fighting for love.<br />A blind mage, a human sacrifice and a big, buff fairy, all fighting off demons to save the world.<br /><br />Twelve writers. Twelve worlds. Twelve warriors.<br /><br />WARRIOR is an anthology of twelve exciting science-fiction and fantasy short stories, bursting with unstoppable characters that happen to identify within the LGBTQIA spectrum.</span>

//<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('rating_details_tip'), "\n      <div id=\"moreBookData\" class=\"bookMeta\" >\n  \n\n  \n\n<table border=\"0\" id=\"rating_distribution\" style=\"width: auto; max-width: 500px;\" cellspacing=\"5\" cellpadding=\"0\">\n      <tr>\n        <th width=\"25\" class=\"right\">5&nbsp;<a size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p10\" style=\"float: right;\"><\/a><\/th>\n        <td width=\"350\">\n          <a style=\"display: block;       $('rating_details_tip').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });
      $('rating_details_tip').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

//]]>
</script>  </div>

<div id="bookReviews">





  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section firstReview">


<div id="review_1945217296" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1945217296" />
    <a title="Rachel (Rustling Reads)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/57578067-rachel-rustling-reads"><img alt="Rachel (Rustling Reads)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1484399444p2/57578067.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1945217296?book_show_action=true">Mar 18, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Rachel (Rustling Reads)" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Rachel (Rustling Reads)" href="/user/show/57578067-rachel-rustling-reads">Rachel (Rustling Reads)</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/57578067-rachel-rustling-reads?shelf=reviewed">reviewed</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/57578067-rachel-rustling-reads?shelf=ace">ace</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/57578067-rachel-rustling-reads?shelf=disability">disability</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/57578067-rachel-rustling-reads?shelf=lgbt">lgbt</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/57578067-rachel-rustling-reads?shelf=racial-diversity">racial-diversity</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1945217296" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer15805301204220617109">First of all, I completely love the story-by-story trigger warnings listed in the front of the collection. These stories do deal with dark themes, and it creates a sense of trust in the collection as a whole right from the beginning, that it will never present you with anything more than you can handle. I’m going to do a brief-ish review of each story, because they’re all great and I need to tell you why. I’ve included the LGBTQIA+ specifics of character identity where I know them.<br /><br />***<br /><br />These Bodie</span>
  <span id="freeText15805301204220617109" style="display:none">First of all, I completely love the story-by-story trigger warnings listed in the front of the collection. These stories do deal with dark themes, and it creates a sense of trust in the collection as a whole right from the beginning, that it will never present you with anything more than you can handle. I’m going to do a brief-ish review of each story, because they’re all great and I need to tell you why. I’ve included the LGBTQIA+ specifics of character identity where I know them.<br /><br />***<br /><br />These Bodies are Battlefields by Tash McAdam – queer romance, genderqueer/non-binary pit fighter and their admirer freeing each other from danger and abuse. This was such a gorgeous way to start this collection, and it’s probably one of my favourite stories overall. There are so many beautiful lines in it that I actually had to pause and just let the whole thing sink in. It’s about defending yourself and others, to not be ashamed of needing help, or having survived trauma. But I think on a deeper level it’s about the difference between surviving and living. Alone, our protagonist is surviving, and with great strength. But together, defending one another, they have the space to actually live, and live joyfully. This is only the beginning, the moment they find one another, but I would absolutely read more about these two.<br /><br />Sole Survivor by Lewis Bright Rees – m/m, though they’ve been separated by the zombie apocalypse. The ‘zombies’ are actually terrifying. I’m honestly still scared of walking around the house at night in case of Smilers. Until I worked out who everyone was, the flashbacks were a little confusing, but this story is in the best tradition of zombie apocalypses, with that yearning for safety, and for the people who mean safety to you.<br /><br />The Seeing Hands of Captain Zerach by Kayla Bashe – blind lesbian mage captain copes with her recent disability, and realises that, in the battle they’re fighting, blindness might actually be an advantage. It’s a beautiful story. Zerach has lost the love of her life and her sight, but she refuses to let others cast her aside. Her blindness will always be a difficulty, but the people around her will not be allowed to forget her skill, and her dedication to winning this fight. Most of the story is away from the battlefield, so there’s space to really feel the depths of these characters.<br /><br />Seida the Fairy-Troll by Claudie Arseneault – the big, buff fairy in the summary above. She likes girls, but the one she has a crush on asserts that she’s asexual, and maybe aromantic. Seida was injured in a childhood mistake and is now ignored by most of the fairies because she has no wings. But when the portal to Hell begins to rip open, only Seida can save the Great Tree, and everyone who lives there. Seida already knows that she’s great, which means that she’s really good fun to read. But it’s time that everyone else realised that she’s great too.<br /><br />Colossus of Ephesus by Tyler Gates – m/m gladiators. This one’s probably one of the sadder ones, but it’s also as literal as you can get in fighting for your love. Helios is just trying to do his best, to live as long as he can. But the gladiator’s life was never going to be easy in that regard, and everything he loves and lives for is on the line.<br /><br />The Metal Mermaid by Kelly Matsuura – lesbian cyborg soldier fights for her friends, for her betrayers, and for her skill and experience to be recognised. I think this was one of the worlds I enjoyed reading the most, and there seem to be some much bigger stories at play here. Reiko has been saved by so many metal parts that by now she’s mostly machine. And that comes in handy on the battlefield, such as when a valuable enemy weapons drop appears to be unguarded on the other side of the river. A river which is deep, and cold, and full of flesh-eating alien monsters. I loved this one, especially when Reiko realises that even though everything doesn’t always go her way, she maybe has more friends than she thought.<br /><br />Howl by Natalie Cannon – werewolves, and not the cute kind. This kind of infection takes your humanity, no matter how hard you try to control it. But when Heather is bitten, there is one thing that might be strong enough to remind her who she really is. Heather has an ex-girlfriend, and her housemate (boyfriend?) uses male pronouns but seems genderqueer in some way. It’s a desperate story of clinging to what really makes you human, and it has this very tangible tension about it which is completely great.<br /><br />Things We’ll Never Know by B R Sanders – black MCs, Aunt Cam is trans. Story of an alien invasion that went very differently to how you’d expect. It’s probably one of the more accurate ideas of how aliens would react to us, and it’s bedded in some very strong family relationships. It’s funny, but it’s also full of sadness and fear, and an unresolved ending – because there is definitely more to this than is on the page.<br /><br />Glass Bones by Kirstie Olley – a completely wonderful mash-up of so much fairy tale tradition, and also magic rings to other-world portals, and at least two gay couples (f/f, m/m). Predictably, given the fairy tale content, this was one of my faves. Mizzy’s brother is cursed with glass bones, and she’s determined to find him a cure. But she might have to sacrifice one person she loves to save the other… Be still, my beating heart. This was so much fun to read.<br /><br />Unnecessary Risks by Abigail Rosenhart – bisexual MC, an old warrior lady sets the story straight. She’s dying, and she demands that this retired scribe copies down the truth of all the tales people tell about her. This is a great way to tell a long story in a short space of time – and it’s unlikely that the legends of Mathilda, the Braided Menace, will die with her – especially given the way she imparts them. There’s such emotion and passion in this story, it’s incredible.<br /><br />Nothing Good to Say by E H Timms – aroace, cursed warrior knows that the fort can’t fend off the approaching raiders – especially since the guildmaster refuses to believe him about the seriousness of the threat. But Cuss is not in the habit of letting innocents die. Through some skilful narrative to-ing and fro-ing, we learn stories from his life. This man has never been interested in relationships, of any kind. But there’s a child in every town who wouldn’t be alive if it weren’t for him. Honestly, this one broke my heart. It’s especially precious to me because of the ace rep, of course, but the writing is so strong that I don’t think anyone could be unaffected by it.<br /><br />From Dust ‘Til Dawn by Hellie Reiersen – a human sacrifice is led across the sands towards her death. At least, that’s the plan. The Daughters have chosen her because she’s trans, but she’s going to prove them all wrong. There’s a lot going on here, and it’s going to take me a second read to work out exactly what happened at the end there, but I absolutely will read it again.<br /><br />***<br /><br />There is not a single weak link in this collection. As promised, twelve warriors, and each one is distinct, strong in different ways and fighting for different causes. Their orientations and identities are not at the forefront of many of the stories, but they matter. If you’re struggling to feel like you belong in stories because of your orientation or gender identity, you should be able to find something for you here. I’m obviously biased to favour the aroace representation, but I connected with so many of these stories. It’s a glorious showcasing of the sheer strength and talent of these writers, and their passion to tell stories which belong to everyone – but, more importantly, stories which represent those who find themselves excluded from mainstream narratives. Honestly, I’d give this six stars if I could.<br /><br />This review was originally published at <a target="_blank" href="https://rustlingreads.wordpress.com/2017/04/03/review-warrior/" rel="nofollow">https://rustlingreads.wordpress.com/2...</a></span>
  <a data-text-id="15805301204220617109" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<div id="review_1823698587" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1823698587" />
    <a title="Hillary" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/13185250-hillary"><img alt="Hillary" src="https://s.gr-assets.com/assets/nophoto/user/f_50x66-6a03a5c12233c941481992b82eea8d23.png" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1823698587?book_show_action=true">Mar 21, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Hillary" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Hillary" href="/user/show/13185250-hillary">Hillary</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/13185250-hillary?shelf=absolute-favorites">absolute-favorites</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/13185250-hillary?shelf=gender-and-sexuality">gender-and-sexuality</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1823698587" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer15967932240045079963">This anthology has something for everyone, from urban fantasy (yay, Natalie!) to historical fiction to high fantasy to science fiction. And unusually for an anthology, there wasn't a single story I didn't like. Everything was crisp, polished, and featured at least one LGBT+ character, though sexuality was never the focus of any of the stories. There were also two asexual characters, a genderfluid character (yay again, Natalie!), and a trans character - all from parts of the LGBT+ spectrum that d</span>
  <span id="freeText15967932240045079963" style="display:none">This anthology has something for everyone, from urban fantasy (yay, Natalie!) to historical fiction to high fantasy to science fiction. And unusually for an anthology, there wasn't a single story I didn't like. Everything was crisp, polished, and featured at least one LGBT+ character, though sexuality was never the focus of any of the stories. There were also two asexual characters, a genderfluid character (yay again, Natalie!), and a trans character - all from parts of the LGBT+ spectrum that don't typically get much representation. READ THIS BOOK! </span>
  <a data-text-id="15967932240045079963" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

Here, you'll find gladiators, werewolves, legends, human sacrifices and mermaids (of a sort), fighting for love, honour, family, truth and life.<br /><br />This anthology was <a href="https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/inkandlocket/warrior-anthology-lgbtqia-short-stories" rel="nofollow">successfully funded on Kickstarter</a> in December 2016. Check the <a href="http://www.inkandlocket.com" rel="nofollow">Ink &amp; Locket Press website</a> to find out when it's available for general preorder.</span>

<div id="review_2228277802" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2228277802" />
    <a title="Alexa" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/10360915-alexa"><img alt="Alexa" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1528574464p2/10360915.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2228277802?book_show_action=true">Aug 07, 2018</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Alexa" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Alexa" href="/user/show/10360915-alexa">Alexa</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=c-fairy">c-fairy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=c-werewolf">c-werewolf</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=g-science-fiction">g-science-fiction</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=g-fantasy">g-fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=lgbt-aromantic-main">lgbt-aromantic-main</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=lgbt-asexual-main">lgbt-asexual-main</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=lgbt-gay-main">lgbt-gay-main</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=lgbt-lesbian-main">lgbt-lesbian-main</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=lgbt-main">lgbt-main</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10360915-alexa?shelf=rated-4-stars">rated-4-stars</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2228277802" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer17659456669087061047">average rating: 3.8 stars<br /><br />This is a collection of stories with queer protagonists. In most stories about queer people, I am used to reading romances, so it was nice to read a collection with queer protagonists where many of the stories have no romance at all, and even in the others, it's usually not the focus.<br /><br />Overall, there weren't any stories that I really hated, but there were several that just didn't really grab my attention. I kind of want to rate this 3 stars but I added up my ratings and th</span>
  <span id="freeText17659456669087061047" style="display:none">average rating: 3.8 stars<br /><br />This is a collection of stories with queer protagonists. In most stories about queer people, I am used to reading romances, so it was nice to read a collection with queer protagonists where many of the stories have no romance at all, and even in the others, it's usually not the focus.<br /><br />Overall, there weren't any stories that I really hated, but there were several that just didn't really grab my attention. I kind of want to rate this 3 stars but I added up my ratings and the average was 3.8 so...<br /><br /><b>the seeing hands of captain zerach by kayla bashe:</b> 4.5 stars. This one is about an older sapphic protagonist who is recently blind and has to learn to adjust to her disability.<br /><b>things we'll never know by b.r. sanders:</b> 5 stars. This is a story about aliens, but also about humanity. Poor/non-white people can't trust aliens because white people fucked them over, and rich/white people can't trust aliens because they fucked people over and think the aliens will do the same to them.<br /><b>glass bones by kirstie olley:</b> 4.5 stars. Fantasy girl and her disabled brother end up visiting our moden world. Also, she's in love with the Lake Maiden. I don't want to spoil the ending, but I'm glad she made the right choice.<br /><b>unnecessary risks by abigail rosenhart:</b> 5 stars. Honestly? Best story. Never saw that twist coming.<br /><b>nothing good to say by e.h. timms:</b> 4.5 stars. Aroace warrior saves kids. Neat.<br /><br /><br />these bodies are battlefields by tash mcadam: 3 stars<br />sole survivor by lewis bright rees: 3 stars<br />seida the fairy-troll by claudie arseneault: 3.5 stars<br />colossus of epheus by tyler gates: 2.5 stars<br />the metal mermaid by kelly matsuura: 3.5 stars<br />howl by natalie cannon: 3 stars<br />from dust 'til dawn by helle reiersen: 3 stars</span>
  <a data-text-id="17659456669087061047" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_1821783566" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1821783566" />
    <a title="Natalie Cannon" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/43815301-natalie-cannon"><img alt="Natalie Cannon" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1445612376p2/43815301.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1821783566?book_show_action=true">May 01, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Natalie Cannon" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Natalie Cannon" href="/user/show/43815301-natalie-cannon">Natalie Cannon</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>

          <span class="greyText">&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;</span> (Review from the author)





    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1821783566" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer5067010035046630708">As one of the authors, I'm biased towards this book from the start. However, this was also the first time I was able to read the other contributors' works. <br /><br />And I am deeply honored.<br /><br />From the beginning with Tash McAdam's ring fighter to Helle Reiersen's Daughter of the Night, every story knocked me right out my usual headspace into a new, starry universe of (blood-drenched) possibility. My heart ached and sang and tore. I reveled in each character's triumph. Each author brought their big guns to th</span>
  <span id="freeText5067010035046630708" style="display:none">As one of the authors, I'm biased towards this book from the start. However, this was also the first time I was able to read the other contributors' works. <br /><br />And I am deeply honored.<br /><br />From the beginning with Tash McAdam's ring fighter to Helle Reiersen's Daughter of the Night, every story knocked me right out my usual headspace into a new, starry universe of (blood-drenched) possibility. My heart ached and sang and tore. I reveled in each character's triumph. Each author brought their big guns to the page, wow-ing me at every plot twist and delighting me with their complex, diverse characters. Is it too late for me to learn knife-throwing? I want to learn knife-throwing after this book, since fairy portal closing and battle mage-fighting are a bit beyond me. <br /><br />So in summary: I laughed, I cried, I want to learn a new skill, and I can't believe my little running werewolf snuck into this phantasmic anthology, among all these fantastic, brilliant, &amp; splendid authors. Thank you for writing and keeping on writing when the going got tough. Thank you to Nica and Amelia, to all the Kickstarter backers, and to everyone who made this anthology possible. Keep fighting and keep writing. </span>
  <a data-text-id="5067010035046630708" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_1880311477" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1880311477" />
    <a title="Louise" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4674421-louise"><img alt="Louise" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1470307476p2/4674421.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1880311477?book_show_action=true">Jun 17, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Louise" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Louise" href="/user/show/4674421-louise">Louise</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4674421-louise?shelf=queer">queer</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4674421-louise?shelf=science-fiction">science-fiction</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4674421-louise?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4674421-louise?shelf=standalone">standalone</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4674421-louise?shelf=sapphic">sapphic</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4674421-louise?shelf=anthologies">anthologies</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1880311477" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer10986877997021146429">Warrior is a great little anthology and it suits my tastes perfectly. Within the twelve stories included, it covers a wide variety of SFF sub-genres and tropes and features representation for a good number of LGBTQIA+ identities.<br /><br /> I'm not great at reviewing short story collections so I thought I'd break things down a little. In fantasy, identities are often implied without using terminology (so that e.g. it can be hard to tell if a character is bi- or pansexual) but for my count, we cover gay, le</span>
  <span id="freeText10986877997021146429" style="display:none">Warrior is a great little anthology and it suits my tastes perfectly. Within the twelve stories included, it covers a wide variety of SFF sub-genres and tropes and features representation for a good number of LGBTQIA+ identities.<br /><br /> I'm not great at reviewing short story collections so I thought I'd break things down a little. In fantasy, identities are often implied without using terminology (so that e.g. it can be hard to tell if a character is bi- or pansexual) but for my count, we cover gay, lesbian, bi/pansexual, trans, intersex and aroace protagonists. Pretty impressive. <br /><br />There was no story that I disliked, and even the ones that aren't really my genre were interesting and well-written. My particular favourites were These Bodies are Battlefields by Tash McAdam, Glass Bones by Kirstie Olley and The Metal Mermaid by Kelly Matsuursa.<br /><br />One of the things I really liked aside from the stories themselves was that there's a short trigger warning page after the contents. It flags things like war, implied sexual assault etc. but (and it bugs me so much when people complain about warnings for this reason) it doesn't give away anything about the stories</span>
  <a data-text-id="10986877997021146429" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<div id="review_1961904372" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1961904372" />
    <a title="Em" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/5852350-em"><img alt="Em" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1471635083p2/5852350.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1961904372?book_show_action=true">Jul 24, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Em" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Em" href="/user/show/5852350-em">Em</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>

          <span class="greyText">&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;</span>
          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/34667997-warrior">review of another edition</a>





          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5852350-em?shelf=books-i-own-kindle">books-i-own-kindle</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5852350-em?shelf=pioqueers-book-club">pioqueers-book-club</a>,

              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5852350-em?shelf=short-stories">short-stories</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5852350-em?shelf=sci-fi">sci-fi</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/5852350-em?shelf=book-riot-read-harder-2017">book-riot-read-harder-2017</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1961904372" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer7145460442815099570">Short stories are really not my thing, but I'm glad my Long Distance College Buddies Discuss Queer Books Club chose it. "Howl" and "Things We'll Never Know" were my favorites. "Howl" was lyrical and beautiful and "Things We'll Never Know" was a perfect science fiction commentary on reality without being obvious or boring about it. Some of the representation (especially of ace and ace spectrum characters) felt more like tokenization but all in all, solid.<br /><br />Book Riot Read Harder 2017 Challenge: 21:</span>
  <span id="freeText7145460442815099570" style="display:none">Short stories are really not my thing, but I'm glad my Long Distance College Buddies Discuss Queer Books Club chose it. "Howl" and "Things We'll Never Know" were my favorites. "Howl" was lyrical and beautiful and "Things We'll Never Know" was a perfect science fiction commentary on reality without being obvious or boring about it. Some of the representation (especially of ace and ace spectrum characters) felt more like tokenization but all in all, solid.<br /><br />Book Riot Read Harder 2017 Challenge: 21: Read a book published by a micropress.<br /><br />(I'm having a hard time getting a concrete definition of "micropress" but per Ink and Locket Press's website they are "not-for-profit, and run mostly on volunteered hours, donations and caffeine" in addition to being small and independent, so I'm counting it.)</span>
  <a data-text-id="7145460442815099570" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>

<span id="freeTextContainer6731210034313138190">This book was a Kickstarter project I backed and I just finished reading it. I loved it. Every story features heroes who identify within the LGBTQIA spectrum. I think I underestimated how delightful that would be to read. It also came with trigger warnings for each individual story. It also reminded me that my favou</span>
  <span id="freeText6731210034313138190" style="display:none">This book was a Kickstarter project I backed and I just finished reading it. I loved it. Every story features heroes who identify within the LGBTQIA spectrum. I think I underestimated how delightful that would be to read. It also came with trigger warnings for each individual story. It also reminded me that my favourite genre is by far YA sci-fi/fantasy. 💖 </span>

<div id="review_1916423454" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1916423454" />
    <a title="Tash McAdam" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/30019967-tash-mcadam"><img alt="Tash McAdam" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442981525p2/30019967.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" rel="nofollow" href="/review/show/1916423454?book_show_action=true">Feb 17, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Tash McAdam" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Tash McAdam" href="/user/show/30019967-tash-mcadam">Tash McAdam</a>
      </span>

        rated it

  var _gaq = _gaq || [];

    _gaq.push.apply(_gaq, arguments);
  }

  GoodreadsAnalytics.push(['_setAccount', 'UA-968618-1']);
  GoodreadsAnalytics.push(['_setCustomVar',
    1,                        // Slot 1
    'User Status',            // Custom variable name
    'signed_out',  // Custom variable value: signed_out, signed_in,
                              //   signed_in_facebook_connected, or
                              //   goodreads_member_previously_signed_in
    2                         // Visit-level scope, which means slot 1 will be
                              //   free when the visit ends.
  ]);
  GoodreadsAnalytics.push(['_setCustomVar',
    2,                        // Slot 2
    'Device Type',            // Custom variable name
    'desktop',         // Custom variable value: desktop, mobile, or
                              //   tablet
    2                         // Visit-level scope, which means slot 2 will be
                              //   free when the visit ends.
  ]);
  GoodreadsAnalytics.push(['_trackPageview']);

  (function () {
    var ga = document.createElement('script');
    ga.type = 'text/javascript';
    ga.async = true;
    ga.src = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https://' : 'http://') + 'stats.g.doubleclick.net/dc.js';
    var s = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
    s.parentNode.insertBefore(ga, s);
  })();

//]]>
</script>

<div id="metacol" class="last col">
<h1 id="bookTitle" class="gr-h1 gr-h1--serif" itemprop="name">
      Her Body and Other Parties
</h1>
<h2 id="bookSeries">
</h2>

<div id="bookAuthors" class="">
  <span class='by'>by</span>
<span itemprop='author' itemscope='' itemtype='http://schema.org/Person'>

<a class="gr-hyperlink" href="#other_reviews">
  <meta itemprop="ratingCount" content="15358">
  <span class="votes value-title" title="15358">
    15,358
  </span>

    <span class="count value-title" title="2601">
      2,601
    </span>

<div id="descriptionContainer">

      <div id="description" class="readable stacked" style="right:0">

<span id="freeTextContainer4214643181548101762">In<i> Her Body and Other Parties</i>, Carmen Maria Machado blithely demolishes the arbitrary borders between psychological realism and science fiction, comedy and horror, fantasy and fabulism. While her work has earned her comparisons to Karen Russell and Kelly Link, she has a voice that is all her own. In this electric and provocative debut, Machado bends genre to shape startlin</span>
  <span id="freeText4214643181548101762" style="display:none">In<i> Her Body and Other Parties</i>, Carmen Maria Machado blithely demolishes the arbitrary borders between psychological realism and science fiction, comedy and horror, fantasy and fabulism. While her work has earned her comparisons to Karen Russell and Kelly Link, she has a voice that is all her own. In this electric and provocative debut, Machado bends genre to shape startling narratives that map the realities of women's lives and the violence visited upon their bodies.<br /><br />A wife refuses her husband's entreaties to remove the green ribbon from around her neck. A woman recounts her sexual encounters as a plague slowly consumes humanity. A salesclerk in a mall makes a horrifying discovery within the seams of the store's prom dresses. One woman's surgery-induced weight loss results in an unwanted houseguest. And in the bravura novella Especially Heinous, Machado reimagines every episode of <i>Law &amp; Order: Special Victims Unit</i>, a show we naively assumed had shown it all, generating a phantasmagoric police procedural full of doppelgangers, ghosts, and girls with bells for eyes.<br /><br />Earthy and otherworldly, antic and sexy, queer and caustic, comic and deadly serious, <i>Her Body and Other Parties</i> swings from horrific violence to the most exquisite sentiment. In their explosive originality, these stories enlarge the possibilities of contemporary fiction.</span>
  <a data-text-id="4214643181548101762" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

      </div>
</div>

  <div id=asyncBuyButtonContainer class="uitext buttons buyableFeature u-marginTopXSmall u-paddingBottomXSmall u-bottomGrayBorder" data-book-id=33375622 >

      $('edition_34198594').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });

      newTip['wrapper'].addClassName('prototipAllowOverflow');

        $('edition_34198594').observe('prototip:shown', function () {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function (e) {
            if ($('edition_34198594').hasClassName('ignored')) {
              e.setStyle({'display': 'none'});
              return;
            }
            e.setStyle({'overflow': 'visible'});
          });
        });
      $('edition_34198594').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

</script></div>

      $('edition_36345284').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});

          $$('div.prototip').each(function (e) {
            if ($('edition_36345284').hasClassName('ignored')) {
              e.setStyle({'display': 'none'});
              return;
            }
            e.setStyle({'overflow': 'visible'});
          });

        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });

<div class='communityQuestion'>
<div class='questionText'>
<a href="/questions/1219332-anyone-have-any-idea-what-the-cover-art">Anyone have any idea what the cover art is? I get the green ribbon reference but I think I&#39;m missing what the red part is (could be a muscle?).</a>
</div>
<div class='communityQAFooter questionFooter'>
<ul class='questionFooterActions'>
<li class='footerItem like'>
<span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_community_question_1219332'><a id="like_count_community_question_1219332" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1219332?resource_type=CommunityQuestion"><span class="likesCount">1 like</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">like</a></span>

</li>
<li class='footerItem communityQuestionTimestamp'>

</li>
<li class='footerItem communityQuestionPermalink'>
<a href="/questions/1219332-anyone-have-any-idea-what-the-cover-art">See all 7 answers</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

<div class='allCommunityAnswers'>
<div class='communityAnswer'>
<div class='communityAnswerBody'>
<div class='answererUserIcon'>
<a class="leftAlignedImage userPhoto" href="/user/show/3393604-susannah"><img alt="" src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/users/1435177816i/3393604._UY100_CR25,0,100,100_.jpg" /></a>
</div>
<div class='communityAnswerTextContainer'>
<span class='communityAnswererName'>
<a href="/user/show/3393604-susannah">Susannah</a>
</span>
<span class='communityAnswerText'>
I think it's a flayed neck - like if you took the top layer of skin off a neck to expose the muscle underneath.
</span>
</div>
</div>

    <a class="uitext" id="span_class_gr-hyperlink_sort_span_default_tip_23" style="cursor: pointer; " href="#" onclick="return false"><span class="gr-hyperlink">Sort</span>: Default</a><script>
//<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('span_class_gr-hyperlink_sort_span_default_tip_23'), "\n        <span class=\"reviewControls__sortOrders\">\n          <span class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"><a class=\"actionLinkLite greyText loadingLink\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-keep-on-success=\"true\" data-remote=\"true\" href=\"/book/reviews/33375622-her-body-and-other-parties?sort=default\">Default<\/a><span class=\"loadingAnimation\"><\/span><span class=\"loadingError\"><\/span><\/span>\n\n          <span class=\"greyText\">&nbsp;|&nbsp;<\/span>\n          <span class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"><a class=\"actionLinkLite  loadingLink\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-keep-on-success=\"true\" data-remote=\"true\" href=\"/book/reviews/33375622-her-body-and-other-parties?sort=newest\">Newest<\/a><span class=\"loadingAnimation\"><\/span><span class=\"loadingError\"><\/span><\/span>\n          <span class=\"greyText\">&nbsp;|&nbsp;<\/span>\n          <span class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"><a class=\"actionLinkLite  loadingLink\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-keep-on-success=\"true\" data-remote=\"true\" href=\"/book/reviews/33375622-her-body-and-other-parties?sort=oldest\">Oldest<\/a><span class=\"loadingAnimation\"><\/span><span class=\"loadingError\"><\/span><\/span>\n        <\/span>\n", { style: 'goodreads', stem: 'topLeft', hook: { tip: 'topLeft', target: 'bottomMiddle' }, offset: { x: 5, y: 5 }, hideOn: false, showOn: 'mouseover', closeButton: false, hideAfter: 1, hideOthers: true });
      $('span_class_gr-hyperlink_sort_span_default_tip_23').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });
      $('span_class_gr-hyperlink_sort_span_default_tip_23').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

    <div class="reviewControls--right">
    <span class="greyText">|</span>
    </div>

    <div class="reviewControls--right">
    <a class="uitext" id="span_class_gr-hyperlink_filter_span_tip_651" style="cursor: pointer; " href="#" onclick="return false"><span class="gr-hyperlink">Filter</span></a><script>

    <div class="section firstReview">


<div id="review_2173005584" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2173005584" />
    <a title="Emily May" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4622890-emily-may"><img alt="Emily May" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1528390751p2/4622890.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2173005584?book_show_action=true">Nov 03, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Emily May" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Emily May" href="/user/show/4622890-emily-may">Emily May</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4622890-emily-may?shelf=short-stories">short-stories</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4622890-emily-may?shelf=2017">2017</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4622890-emily-may?shelf=feminism">feminism</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2173005584" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer1316120712675651067">This is a difficult review to write because I have a lot of mixed feelings.<br /><br /><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/33375622.Her_Body_and_Other_Parties" title="Her Body and Other Parties by Carmen Maria Machado" rel="nofollow">Her Body and Other Parties</a> is like most short story collections I have read in that some of the stories worked for me far more than others. It is<b> a strange, experimental, feminist collection</b> that often crosses into fantasy, dystopia and/or magical realism. Some of the stories stepped out of the land of weird into, I feel, the land of nonsensical and absurdist. I liked these stories less than the others.<br /><br />Perhaps it is somew</span>
  <span id="freeText1316120712675651067" style="display:none">This is a difficult review to write because I have a lot of mixed feelings.<br /><br /><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/33375622.Her_Body_and_Other_Parties" title="Her Body and Other Parties by Carmen Maria Machado" rel="nofollow">Her Body and Other Parties</a> is like most short story collections I have read in that some of the stories worked for me far more than others. It is<b> a strange, experimental, feminist collection</b> that often crosses into fantasy, dystopia and/or magical realism. Some of the stories stepped out of the land of weird into, I feel, the land of nonsensical and absurdist. I liked these stories less than the others.<br /><br />Perhaps it is somewhat plebeian of me to say so, but I preferred the stories with actual, you know, <i>stories</i> and a structural narrative. My favourites were the much-lauded "The Husband Stitch", "Eight Bites", and "Difficult At Parties". <br /><br />"The Husband Stitch" is a retelling of "The Green Ribbon" with emphasis on the demands men and society place on women, and their sense of entitlement toward women's bodies. I especially liked how the author played around with form, including stage directions for the reader who is “reading this story out loud”. <br /><br />"Eight Bites" is about a woman's relationship with food and her fat self as she considers and then gets bariatric surgery. Machado's evocative writing really worked when delving into a food/body obsession. <br /><br />"Difficult At Parties" - about a woman trying to deal with the aftermath of sexual assault by watching porn - is another narrative that got right under my skin.<br /><br />I also enjoyed "The Resident", in which an artist's retreat in the mountains leads to a writer slowly coming undone. It contained a darkly comical line that is one of my favourite quotes in the collection: <br /><blockquote>
  <i>“Do you ever worry,” she asked me, “that you’re the madwoman in the attic?”</i>
</blockquote><br />"Mothers", on the other hand, was a bit too abstract for me. I'd be lying if I claimed to really understand what happened. Though my least favourites were "Inventory" and "Especially Heinous". The former lists the narrator's sexual experiences throughout her life in snippets, as a vague post-apocalyptic scenario plays out in the background. <br /><br />"Especially Heinous" should have been called "Especially Tedious". It rewrites the episode plot summaries for twelve seasons of <i>Law &amp; Order: SVU</i> in snippets that gave me flashbacks to <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/29906980.Lincoln_in_the_Bardo" title="Lincoln in the Bardo by George Saunders" rel="nofollow">Lincoln in the Bardo</a>. It's just page after page of disconnected plot summaries that didn't come together and do anything. I wanted it to end.<br /><br />However, just in general - and this can hardly be considered Machado's fault - I am growing a little tired of these feminist tales that hold such a grim definition of womanhood and femininity. Where we are painted as humans owned in parts by various men and corporations, where sex is cold and passionless, where we are seen to be masturbating furiously whenever our vaginas aren’t bleeding, which seems to be 80% of the time with all the hymens, birthing and, of course, menstruation. Maybe this is to make women seem harder, more brutal, less maternal and nurturing and cuddly and weak… but it’s a bleak alternative. <br /><br />This book, in particular, is heavy on the sex. I have no problem with sex and sexuality, but it's extremely detached and unemotional. It's an orgasm with a straight face. It's this quote from "Real Women Have Bodies" when the narrator's girlfriend is dying/fading: <br /><blockquote>
  <i>“We have never fucked with such urgency as we do in these weeks, but she is fading more and feeling less. She comes infrequently.”</i>
</blockquote><br />It is sometimes very strange how sex and coming are the most important things in scenes where it seems like far more important things are happening. It made it especially difficult to read through "Inventory", which is little more than a repetitive listing of unsexy sex throughout a woman's life.<br /><br />My personal thoughts about the direction of feminist lit aside, I thought <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/33375622.Her_Body_and_Other_Parties" title="Her Body and Other Parties by Carmen Maria Machado" rel="nofollow">Her Body and Other Parties</a> was pretty mixed overall. I would recommend Gay's <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/28818921.Difficult_Women" title="Difficult Women by Roxane Gay" rel="nofollow">Difficult Women</a>, 404 Ink's <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/33022718.Nasty_Women" title="Nasty Women by 404 Ink" rel="nofollow">Nasty Women</a> or Enriquez's <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/30375706.Things_We_Lost_in_the_Fire" title="Things We Lost in the Fire by Mariana Enríquez" rel="nofollow">Things We Lost in the Fire</a> before this book. Though some stories are definitely worth checking out.<br /><br /><a href="http://thebookgeek.org" rel="nofollow">Blog</a> | <a href="https://www.facebook.com/thebookgeekreviews" rel="nofollow">Facebook</a> | <a href="https://twitter.com/thebookgeek01" rel="nofollow">Twitter</a> | <a href="http://instagram.com/emleemay" rel="nofollow">Instagram</a> | <a href="https://www.youtube.com/c/EmilyMayTheBookGeek" rel="nofollow">Youtube</a></span>
  <a data-text-id="1316120712675651067" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<div id="review_1966724800" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1966724800" />
    <a title="Roxane" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1151637-roxane"><img alt="Roxane" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442511711p2/1151637.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1966724800?book_show_action=true">Apr 09, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Roxane" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Roxane" href="/user/show/1151637-roxane">Roxane</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1966724800" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer1567723603504623702">The stories in Carmen Maria Machado’s Her Body and Other Parties vibrate with originality, queerness, sensuality and the strange. Her voracious imagination and extraordinary voice beautifully bind these stories about fading women and the end of the world and men who want more when they’ve been given everything and bodies, so many human bodies taking up space and straining the seams of skin in impossible, imperfect, unforgettable ways.</span>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1966724800'><a id="like_count_review_1966724800" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1966724800?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">346 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>

  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2148120916" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2148120916" />
    <a title="Larry H" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/5872506-larry-h"><img alt="Larry H" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1530046157p2/5872506.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2148120916?book_show_action=true">Oct 10, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Larry H" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Larry H" href="/user/show/5872506-larry-h">Larry H</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2148120916" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer10138863596992410419">I'd rate this 4.5 stars.<br /><br />If you think of works of fiction like works of art, Carmen Maria Machado's debut story collection, <b> <i>Her Body and Other Parties</i> </b>, is an abstract painting. It's undoubtedly gorgeous and attention-getting, there's no one right way to interpret the things you see (or read), everyone will see something different in it, and each time you look, you'll catch something you didn't see the first time. You may also find yourself wondering, "What did that mean?"<br /><br />Seven of the eight stor</span>
  <span id="freeText10138863596992410419" style="display:none">I'd rate this 4.5 stars.<br /><br />If you think of works of fiction like works of art, Carmen Maria Machado's debut story collection, <b>
  <i>Her Body and Other Parties</i>
</b>, is an abstract painting. It's undoubtedly gorgeous and attention-getting, there's no one right way to interpret the things you see (or read), everyone will see something different in it, and each time you look, you'll catch something you didn't see the first time. You may also find yourself wondering, "What did that mean?"<br /><br />Seven of the eight stories in this collection are a mesmerizing combination of atmosphere, sexuality, emotion, and gorgeous, gorgeous storytelling. There is also a strange undercurrent of creepiness running through many of the stories. I'll admit I was a little bit nervous while reading, and I kept waiting for something horrible, for a bogeyman to reveal itself, or some shocking event to occur. That tension is almost addictive, because you want to keep on reading, wondering just what Machado has up her sleeve. <br /><br />The stories that stood out the most for me were "Inventory," in which a woman recounts her sexual exploits as the world is slowly being consumed by an unexplained plague; "Real Women Have Bodies," where a young woman working at a prom dress shop makes a shocking discovery about what makes the store's gowns so unique; "Eight Bites," about a woman visited by an unwanted houseguest after weight loss surgery; the immensely creepy "The Resident," in which a writer at an artist's colony has trouble with the lines blurring between past and present, fact and fiction; and the sexy, mysterious "The Husband Stitch," where a woman's husband has been begging her for years to remove the green ribbon from around her neck, but she never has.<br /><br />The one story, which is more of a novella, that absolutely didn't work for me, was "Especially Heinous," a spoof of sorts of <b>
  <i>Law and Order: SVU</i>
</b>, which provided brief synopses of 272 episodes of the show, adding supernatural elements, ramping up the show's sexual tension and emotional instability, and throwing in some mundane twists as well. I just didn't get it, and it dragged on far too long for me, but I've seen other reviews refer to this as the best in the collection, so what do I know?<br /><br /><b>
  <i>Her Body and Other Parties</i>
</b> is a finalist for the National Book Award for Fiction, and it is truly the debut of a dazzling, fearless new voice in the world of short stories. While I wish I could talk to someone about what they think happened in some of the stories, I honestly can't stop thinking about the worlds Machado created, and how masterfully she reeled me into them.<br /><br />This isn't a collection for those who like their stories to be more straightforward, or those uncomfortable with sex scenes both implied and explicit, but if you're in the mood for some genre-defying fiction, pick up this collection. You'll get to witness the start of what is sure to be an incredible career.<br /><br />See all of my reviews at <a target="_blank" href="http://itseithersadnessoreuphoria.blogspot.com" rel="nofollow">http://itseithersadnessoreuphoria.blo...</a>.</span>
  <a data-text-id="10138863596992410419" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2148120916'><a id="like_count_review_2148120916" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/2148120916?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">161 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2065859280" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2065859280" />
    <a title="Melanie" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3030788-melanie"><img alt="Melanie" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1514836856p2/3030788.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2065859280?book_show_action=true">Nov 13, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Melanie" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Melanie" href="/user/show/3030788-melanie">Melanie</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=feminism">feminism</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=horror">horror</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=contemporary">contemporary</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=novellas-and-short-stories">novellas-and-short-stories</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=lgbtqiap">lgbtqiap</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=buddy-reads">buddy-reads</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=read-in-2017">read-in-2017</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2065859280" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer2750125673777552497">This collection of short stories heavily emphasizes the violence that we put on women’s bodies. Whether it be sexual violence, physical violence, violence put on us by society, or violence we put on ourselves. This entire collection is absolutely haunting in the best way possible. I won’t forget this collection, ever. And these are all so queer, and so feminist, and invoked so many emotions from me. Carmen Maria Machado is beyond words talented, and I feel so very blessed to even have been able</span>
  <span id="freeText2750125673777552497" style="display:none">This collection of short stories heavily emphasizes the violence that we put on women’s bodies. Whether it be sexual violence, physical violence, violence put on us by society, or violence we put on ourselves. This entire collection is absolutely haunting in the best way possible. I won’t forget this collection, ever. And these are all so queer, and so feminist, and invoked so many emotions from me. Carmen Maria Machado is beyond words talented, and I feel so very blessed to even have been able to read this. <br><br>I'm going to break down each short story with my thoughts, opinions, and individual star rating! <br><br>➽ <u>
  <b>
    <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2022000856" rel="nofollow">THE HUSBAND STITCH</a>
  </b>
</u> - ★★★★★<br>This is my second time reading this, and it is just as powerful and hard hitting as it was the first time around. You can read this for free <a href="https://granta.com/the-husband-stitch/" rel="nofollow">from Granta</a>!, and I implore each and every one of you who is reading this review to do yourself a favor and read this short story. <br><br>This story is very feminist and very sexually explicit, but so damn important. It's about the life of a woman, who gives everything to men and never is allowed to keep anything for herself. It's about life's expectations on women, and how society shapes the choices we do and do not have. It's about how, no matter what, giving everything will never be good enough as a woman. It's about enjoying and exploring your sexuality, yet trying to cope with the shame. It's about never fully being able to become the person you are, but becoming the person your husband and/or family require you to be. It's about having children, who will just repeat the same vicious and unfair cycle. <b>This is my favorite short story of all time</b> and it deserves all the stars that Goodreads and every other book rating site has to offer. <br><br>➽ <u>
  <b>INVENTORY</b>
</u> - ★★★★<br>This is essentially an inventory list of all the sexual encounters this particular woman has had during her thirty years while her world escalates into chaos. I loved looking at this sexual exploration, journey, and acceptance. And it evoked such raw emotion from me. I just didn’t think it was as hard hitting as some of the others in the collection.<br><br>Also, if you enjoyed this short story, please check out <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1733216850" rel="nofollow">The Book of the Unnamed Midwife</a> by Meg Elison! I honestly can’t recommend it enough, and both stories have a similar theme, feeling, and hauntingness to them. <br><br>➽ <u>
  <b>MOTHERS</b>
</u> - ★★★<br>This is a very metaphorical story that starts out with a woman being given a baby by her female lover that they created unbeknownst to the narrator. And I use the word narrator very loosely, because this story is very unreliable. You will constantly be unsure of what is real and what is not, but you slowly get to see a story unfold. I also wholeheartedly believe that this story is very open for interpretation, and what I got from it could be, and probably is, something very different from what you were able to take from it. And that in and of itself is beyond words beautiful. <br><br>➽ <u>
  <b>ESPECIALLY HEINOUS</b>
</u> - ★★<br>This is a retelling of each season and episode of <i>Law &amp; Order: SVU</i> that dips into the realm of the paranormal, but because I have never seen that show (I know, I know) I don’t think I got that much enjoyment out of this one. I still thought it was so very smartly written, and it has that haunting feeling that I know associate with Carmen Maria Machado, but I just wasn’t as in love with this as I feel others will be.<br><br>➽ <u>
  <b>REAL WOMEN HAVE BODIES</b>
</u> - ★★★★★<br>This story felt like a punch to the gut over and over and over. Words can be so powerful, and Carmen Maria Machado has perfected the craft of writing, I swear. Women in this world fade slowly and eventually become invisible. We get to see a dress shop, that puts youth and beautiful before all else, and a few of the workers are grasping to those values. Growing older, and feeling less valuable because of it, is a concept that many people in this world can’t deal with, without having to turn invisible. And I’m not going to lie to you and say that when I read that one of the characters of this book was twenty-nine that I didn’t try to suppress that visceral feeling that I don’t even have words for, but I wish so badly that I didn’t feel.<br><br>➽ <u>
  <b>EIGHT BITES</b>
</u> - ★★★★★<br>First and foremost, this short story would be so very trigging for anyone who has battled any form of eating disorder before, so please use caution before reading this one. Food and body obsession is so very real, and people will go their entire lives never knowing peace with themselves because of it. This is a story about a woman who has struggled her entire life and has finally decided to get bariatric surgery. This story also heavily talks about how we pass these terrible feelings and values down to our daughters and other generations, over and over. <br><br>➽ <u>
  <b>THE RESIDENT</b>
</u> - ★★★<br>Like most of the stories in this collection, this story felt really personal to read. Like, autobiographical personal. This is about a woman who goes up to the mountains, where she also spent some of her youth as a Girl Scout, to work on her novel among other artists. We slowly get to see the writer slowly comes undone by her past and her present, but also embraces and comes to terms with who she is and how she is. It’s a beautiful mixture that I think most humans will really resonate with. <br><br>➽ <u>
  <b>DIFFICULT AT PARTIES</b>
</u> - ★★★★<br>This was probably the most raw feeling story for me, and it really left me feeling empty. This is about a woman dealing, coping, and trying to heal with the aftermath of a sexual assault. Between others trying to help her, to hoping her assailant is found, and trying to find some sort of peace within herself, she is using pornography as a healing mechanism. Again, this is going to really be hard for a lot of people to read, but it’s also going to hit home for so many readers that need stories like this. <br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1511810302i/24545935._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I really loved this collection, and I gave <i>Her Body and Other Parties</i> 4 stars overall, because out of a possible 40 stars (5 stars possible for each of the 8 stories) this collection accumulated 31 stars <b>(77%)</b>. Please pick this up, this is such an important book for everyone to read, and I can’t recommend it enough. <br><br><a href="https://meltotheany.wordpress.com/" rel="nofollow">Blog</a> | <a href="https://www.twitter.com/meltotheany" rel="nofollow">Twitter</a> | <a href="http://meltotheany.tumblr.com/" rel="nofollow">Tumblr</a> | <a href="https://www.instagram.com/meltotheany/" rel="nofollow">Instagram</a> | <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC4RbHEg_fH6CewJrh_0xJ9g" rel="nofollow">Youtube</a> | <a href="http://www.twitch.tv/meltotheany" rel="nofollow">Twitch</a> <br><br>Buddy read with <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/2432645-lilly-lair-of-books" rel="nofollow">Lilly</a>, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/52545435-elise-thebookishactress-on-wordpress" rel="nofollow">Elise</a>, &amp; <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/15335689-destiny-howling-libraries" rel="nofollow">Destiny</a>! ❤</span>
  <a data-text-id="2750125673777552497" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>

I always think "did I miss something?" I'll check back after I read the rest.</span>

<div id="review_2142400541" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2142400541" />
    <a title="Navidad Thelamour" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/50404233-navidad-thelamour"><img alt="Navidad Thelamour" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1501036014p2/50404233.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2142400541?book_show_action=true">Oct 03, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Navidad Thelamour" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Navidad Thelamour" href="/user/show/50404233-navidad-thelamour">Navidad Thelamour</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50404233-navidad-thelamour?shelf=dnf">dnf</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50404233-navidad-thelamour?shelf=group-reads">group-reads</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50404233-navidad-thelamour?shelf=mini-review">mini-review</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50404233-navidad-thelamour?shelf=read-2017">read-2017</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50404233-navidad-thelamour?shelf=short-story-collections">short-story-collections</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50404233-navidad-thelamour?shelf=supernatural">supernatural</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50404233-navidad-thelamour?shelf=gothic">gothic</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50404233-navidad-thelamour?shelf=women-s-fiction">women-s-fiction</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/50404233-navidad-thelamour?shelf=reviewed-on-amazon">reviewed-on-amazon</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2142400541" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer15896440650887890183"><b>2.5 stars</b><br /><br />Carmen Maria Machado's <i>Her Body and Other Parties</i> is a collection I was so excited to read I dragged a friend in to read it with me. We handed off back and forth who got to pick the next story, never going in order, and found ourselves surprisingly disappointed by each one. <br /><br />In all honesty, I was <i>drawn</i> to what Machado was trying to do here, to what she was trying to say. But, she didn't say it with enough force. Some of her stories, such as "Real Women Have Bodies" and "Eight Bites" seem</span>
  <span id="freeText15896440650887890183" style="display:none"><b>2.5 stars</b><br /><br />Carmen Maria Machado's <i>Her Body and Other Parties</i> is a collection I was so excited to read I dragged a friend in to read it with me. We handed off back and forth who got to pick the next story, never going in order, and found ourselves surprisingly disappointed by each one. <br /><br />In all honesty, I was <i>drawn</i> to what Machado was trying to do here, to what she was trying to say. But, she didn't say it with enough force. Some of her stories, such as "Real Women Have Bodies" and "Eight Bites" seemed to not amount to much more than a harsh whisper, if that, never fully realizing themselves. I wanted more--<b>MORE</b> from a voice that dared to tackle such bold topics as the female experience and psyche. And by "more" I don't mean argumentative or domineering in tone; some of my favorite short stories <i>ever</i> crept up on me with a gentle breeze at my neck only to bowl me over in the end with words just as gentle. Machado and <i>Her Body</i> didn't do that for me. In fact, what I remember most about this collection is my buddy reader's and my disappointed-mounting-to-annoyed reaction as each story was read and discussed. For such a topic that spoke to us, we both wanted to learn something, to feel something--<i>something</i>. This collection just fell flat in so many ways.<br /><br />Here's what I will say: Carmen Maria Machado clearly has something to say, though I, myself, didn't hear it loudly enough. I <i>thoroughly</i> enjoyed her use of Gothic elements--vaguely supernatural devices used to convey her thoughts, to tinge her messages in wonder. Yet, some of her works were too referential without adding enough to the conversation to warrant the blatant references (to "The Girl with the Ribbon Around her Neck" and <i>Law &amp; Order: SVU</i> in particular). "The Husband Stitch" was my favorite story, because of the unique and haunting asides inserted into the narrative, but the ending failed to shock or move me, so even that story did not live up to the hype around this collection. Every story I read left me wishing there was more--not length but meat and substance, not words but voice and resonance. As we all know, fabulously original ideas must, too, be supported by the execution of them, and <i>that</i> I did not see impressively done here. 2.5* <br /><br /><b>FOLLOW ME AT:</b><br /><br /><a href="https://thenavireview.com/" rel="nofollow">The Navi Review Blog</a> | <a href="https://twitter.com/thenavireview" rel="nofollow">Twitter</a> | <a href="https://www.instagram.com/thenavireview/" rel="nofollow">Instagram</a></span>
  <a data-text-id="15896440650887890183" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2142400541'><a id="like_count_review_2142400541" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/2142400541?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">146 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>
