  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2463016769" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2463016769" />
    <a title="Amalia Gavea" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/56789747-amalia-gavea"><img alt="Amalia Gavea" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1477958579p2/56789747.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2463016769?book_show_action=true">Jul 30, 2018</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Amalia Gavea" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Amalia Gavea" href="/user/show/56789747-amalia-gavea">Amalia Gavea</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>

          <span class="greyText">&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;</span>
          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/34198594-her-body-and-other-parties">review of another edition</a>





          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=american-literature">american-literature</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=contemporary">contemporary</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=crossover">crossover</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=gothic-fiction">gothic-fiction</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=literary-fiction">literary-fiction</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=magical-realism">magical-realism</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=mystery-horror">mystery-horror</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/56789747-amalia-gavea?shelf=short-stories">short-stories</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2463016769" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer7254254419004463616"><i> <b>‘’What magical thing could you want so badly they take you away from the known world for wanting it?’’</b> </i><br /><br />This book is one of those cases when you feel someone calling your name. From the enticing cover to the cryptic tale. Naturally, this being a short story collection falling into Literary Fiction, Magical Realism and Gender Studies, finding itself in my hands was unavoidable. This proved to be a very special, extreme adventure.<br /><br />Machado writes with bravery, clarity, and confidence, centering her</span>
  <span id="freeText7254254419004463616" style="display:none"><i>
  <b>‘’What magical thing could you want so badly they take you away from the known world for wanting it?’’</b>
</i><br /><br />This book is one of those cases when you feel someone calling your name. From the enticing cover to the cryptic tale. Naturally, this being a short story collection falling into Literary Fiction, Magical Realism and Gender Studies, finding itself in my hands was unavoidable. This proved to be a very special, extreme adventure.<br /><br />Machado writes with bravery, clarity, and confidence, centering her stories on sexuality and beauty from the perspective of women who do not follow the flow or adjust to society’s demands and conformities. In frank, open, haunting writing, she stresses how the body becomes a projection of the way women have been viewed- and are still viewed- in our societies. Beauty, sexuality, everything is preconceived, even in our modern, sophisticated world. More so now, I believe. Many support- either consciously or not- that you must change when you are different or you will find yourself ostracised. This notion was obviously much more common in the past. In my opinion, today we have a different kind of isolation. The psychological imprisonment, the bullying, the feeling that you simply aren’t good enough. We let others decide and throw parties on our bodies and our souls. Why? Because we need acceptance. What if we don’t find fit the image of beauty and grace others have already cultivated for us?<br /><br /><i>
  <b>The Husband Stitch</b>
</i>: A woman, born with a green ribbon on her neck, finds love and creates a beautiful family. Or does she? A dark tale that becomes darker with references to urban legends and tragic folk myths. Absolutely brilliant.<br /><i>
  <b>Inventory</b>
</i>: A woman remembers past lovers as a deathly virus is slowly destroying the country. <br /><i>
  <b>Mothers</b>
</i>: A very complex story, centered around a horribly dysfunctional relationship, where reality blends with the memories of a shattered mind. This is one of the most powerful moments in the collection.<br /><br /><i>
  <b>‘’Stabler never told Benson about his little brother. But he also never told her about his older brother, which was understandable, because he didn’t know about him, either’’ </b>
</i>(If this isn’t perfect sarcasm, I don’t know what is…)<br /><br /><i>
  <b>Especially Heinous</b>
</i>: Machado imagines plot lines for episodes of the TV series <i>Law and Order: SVU</i> or whatever its name is. Frankly, they are so much better than the actual episodes of the actual series. The only problem is I found this to be completely irrelevant to the overall tone of the collection but it was hugely entertaining.<br /><i>
  <b>Real Women Have Bodies</b>
</i>: Women become mist. Suddenly and without any comprehensible cause. They turn invisible while clothes become alive. This is a story of the complex relationship between us and our bodies which become even more perplexing as we grow up. Body positivity, anorexia, the notion adopted by many men that our bodies are theirs to use as they see fit since the beginning of time. Who and what decides how a ‘’real’’ woman should look like? This is such a beautiful, tragic tale with a beautiful relationship at its heart and haunting descriptions of the misty women.<br /><br /><i>
  <b>‘’Foxes wove through the streets at night. There was a white one among them, sleek and fast, and she looked like the ghost of the others.’’</b>
</i><br /><br /><i>
  <b>Eight Bites</b>
</i>: One of the most profound stories in the collection. Young women have to undergo surgeries to remain thin. Eight bites. That’s what they can eat. Eight bites to keep the perfect body intact.<br /><br /><i>
  <b>‘’Do you ever worry’’, she asked me, ‘’that you’re the madwoman in the attic?’’</b>
</i><br /><br /><i>
  <b>The Resident</b>
</i>: This is the most perplexing story in the collection. It gave me quite a lot of trouble in trying to classify it so to speak. A woman finds herself in an old-fashioned hotel, occupied by bohemian artists that are not what they seem. Is it a horror story? An allegory? Probably a combination of the two. It is certainly haunting, sensual and atmospheric but I didn’t find it particularly interesting. If anything, it seemed a bit pretentious.<br /><i>
  <b>Difficult at Parties</b>
</i>: A story of trauma, abuse and obsession that crosses the lines. I found parts of this tale distasteful and, for me, this was the dud of the collection.<br /><br />Despite the (very) few issues, this is a raw, haunting, brave collection. I recommend it without any hesitation but I don’t think it is for everyone. If you are uncomfortable with certain dark thematic elements, there’s a chance you may not enjoy it. However, I know that most of us are brave readers, attracted to dark and controversial themes and to books that make us think….<br /><br /><i>
  <b>‘’There are strange evenings when the sun sets but it rains anyway, and the sky is gold and peach and also gray and purple like a bruise. Every morning, a fine mist coats the grove. Some nights, a bloody harvest moon rises over the horizon and stains the clouds like an alien sunrise.’’</b>
</i><br /><br />My reviews can also be found on <a target="_blank" href="https://theopinionatedreaderblog.wordpress.com" rel="nofollow">https://theopinionatedreaderblog.word...</a></span>
  <a data-text-id="7254254419004463616" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<div id="review_2299810406" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2299810406" />
    <a title="Elyse" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/597461-elyse"><img alt="Elyse" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1514246949p2/597461.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2299810406?book_show_action=true">Feb 18, 2018</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Elyse" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Elyse" href="/user/show/597461-elyse">Elyse</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>

          <span class="greyText">&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;</span>
          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/34198594-her-body-and-other-parties">review of another edition</a>





    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2299810406" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer8544191828365233717">It’s 3am... <br />I really need to fall back to sleep ...<br />but I couldn’t stop reading these stories so before I drift off..<br />I’ll just say a few things...<br />ITS NOT FOR THE TIMID....<br /><br />I had read two of the stories yesterday and couldn’t stop talking to Paul about them on our hike yesterday. I was trying to figure them out. They are easy to read - but requires our interpretation. <br />I just now finished the rest... some were even harder to wrap my head around. These are literary - kinda brilliant- short stories-wh</span>
  <span id="freeText8544191828365233717" style="display:none">It’s 3am... <br />I really need to fall back to sleep ...<br />but I couldn’t stop reading these stories so before I drift off..<br />I’ll just say a few things...<br />ITS NOT FOR THE TIMID....<br /><br />I had read two of the stories yesterday and couldn’t stop talking to Paul about them on our hike yesterday. I was trying to figure them out. They are easy to read - but requires our interpretation. <br />I just now finished the rest... some were even harder to wrap my head around. These are literary - kinda brilliant- short stories-which a classroom discussion could enhance. <br /><br />Lots of SEX..so let’s just get that out there ....<br />However sex in these stories is a broad word. <br /><br />The writing is beautiful- gorgeous- addictive- intense - elegant - powerful - disturbing- erotic - heartbreaking- horrific - <br /><br />Women are vulnerable- their souls are split open - there is a sense of doom - <br /><br />I still don’t understand all of these stories and I’m not sure I’m suppose to... and a few I liked more than others <br /><br />Paul and I discussed the symbolism of a green ribbon - <br />We talked about a story ‘Inventory’ .... sex partners....<br />The last story - ( I knew it was from rape) - but it’s not graphic..... left me hurting,<br /><br />At the same time there is life energy in these stories through women’s bodies....beautiful women’s bodies...<br /><br />A thought provoking unique collection of stories by one hell of a gifted artistic writer ....<br />I’m left breathless!!!!<br /></span>
  <a data-text-id="8544191828365233717" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>

<div id="review_1975263116" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1975263116" />
    <a title="Jenny (Reading Envy)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/68030-jenny-reading-envy"><img alt="Jenny (Reading Envy)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1455391853p2/68030.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1975263116?book_show_action=true">Apr 18, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Jenny (Reading Envy)" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Jenny (Reading Envy)" href="/user/show/68030-jenny-reading-envy">Jenny (Reading Envy)</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/68030-jenny-reading-envy?shelf=audiobook">audiobook</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/68030-jenny-reading-envy?shelf=hoopla">hoopla</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/68030-jenny-reading-envy?shelf=read2017">read2017</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/68030-jenny-reading-envy?shelf=national-book-award-nominees">national-book-award-nominees</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1975263116" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer15874304386146244442">I ordered this for my library but grew impatient and listened to it on Hoopla instead. It is one of the finalists for the 2017 National Book Award (USA.)<br /><br />This is a book of short stories, all centering around the female body, as evidenced by the title. This would not be a book for anyone who shocks easily, as there is sex, a lot of sex, some of it queer sex, and some of it deals with the aftermath of sexual assault. Some of the themes are disturbing, and the insertion at times of supernatural or f</span>
  <span id="freeText15874304386146244442" style="display:none">I ordered this for my library but grew impatient and listened to it on Hoopla instead. It is one of the finalists for the 2017 National Book Award (USA.)<br /><br />This is a book of short stories, all centering around the female body, as evidenced by the title. This would not be a book for anyone who shocks easily, as there is sex, a lot of sex, some of it queer sex, and some of it deals with the aftermath of sexual assault. Some of the themes are disturbing, and the insertion at times of supernatural or fantastical elements make many of the stories feel even more dangerous than real life, or maybe it's that they highlight the danger of real life. The writing is powerful and I would not be surprised to see this win the award, although I'm still slightly more on board with <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/32920226.Sing__Unburied__Sing" title="Sing, Unburied, Sing by Jesmyn Ward" rel="nofollow">Sing, Unburied, Sing</a>.<br /><br />Story by story:<br /><br />The Husband Stitch - This is a retelling of The Girl with the Ribbon Around her Neck, but somehow the husband is more domineering, and the lengthening of the story brings you more into her point of view.<br /><br />Inventory - A list of sexual encounters inside the context of a world falling apart due to a virus. This might be my favorite!<br /><br />Mothers - A disturbing story where I couldn't tell what was real and what was not. A baby delivered by her lesbian partner, told "this is your baby," But then she is running through the park after stranger babies...<br /><br />Especially Heinous - I could not understand what was going on here, and had to stop and look up some info about the book. The author has taken every episode of SVU, the show that focuses on sex crimes, usually against women, and builds an alternative story where women have bell eyes and something supernatural is going on and I just didn't really get it at all. I'm sure if I had any familiarity at all with SVU the characters at least would make sense to me, but this was rough. And since it was in audio, I couldn't tell if this was a series of very short stories (flash stories) or what I was encountering, because the author keeps the title of each episode and then has a paragraph or a sentence after each. I wish it had an intro or something, at least to navigate the audio verison.<br /><br />Real Women Have Bodies - If women really grew invisible....<br /><br />Eight Bites - Well I'm not quite sure, but I think this is about weight loss surgery and the sacrifice of thin and what it does to our daughters? It's rather frightening.<br /><br />The Resident - This one examines whether female writers are allowed to write about themselves the same way male writers are, what makes something art, how much autonomy do you have as a creative person?<br /><br />Difficult at Parties - A woman has gone through severe trauma and starts hearing the thoughts of actors on film.. and in the background, a spouse trying desperately to help.</span>
  <a data-text-id="15874304386146244442" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1975263116'><a id="like_count_review_1975263116" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1975263116?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">85 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>

  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2149724750" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2149724750" />
    <a title="Joe Valdez" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/26876584-joe-valdez"><img alt="Joe Valdez" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1508005185p2/26876584.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2149724750?book_show_action=true">Oct 10, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Joe Valdez" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Joe Valdez" href="/user/show/26876584-joe-valdez">Joe Valdez</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was ok"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/26876584-joe-valdez?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/26876584-joe-valdez?shelf=anthology">anthology</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2149724750" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer1167363182437560733"><i>Her Body and Other Parties</i> is the debut book by Carmen Maria Machado, whose movie reviews I was familiar with in the <i>Los Angeles Times</i>. Published in 2017, I bit on this short story collection with the publisher's promise of fiction that "borders between psychological realism and science fiction, comedy and horror, fantasy and fabulism." I found it to be rough in terms of quality control, a talented beginner trying way too hard. The first and second of eight pieces are terrific but everything tha</span>
  <span id="freeText1167363182437560733" style="display:none"><i>Her Body and Other Parties</i> is the debut book by Carmen Maria Machado, whose movie reviews I was familiar with in the <i>Los Angeles Times</i>. Published in 2017, I bit on this short story collection with the publisher's promise of fiction that "borders between psychological realism and science fiction, comedy and horror, fantasy and fabulism." I found it to be rough in terms of quality control, a talented beginner trying way too hard. The first and second of eight pieces are terrific but everything that follows alternates wildly between undeveloped workshop draft and smart ass social media post. Obscurity overwhelms clarity.<br /><br />"The Husband Stitch" is the tale of a woman who wears a green ribbon around her neck that she never removes. At seventeen, she meets the man she'll marry, and manages to keep her ribbon and its secrets secure until their son goes off to college. The Writing (with a capital W, ugh) is style heavy--which should have been a red flag for me--but Machado did keep me unsettled throughout by grounding her story in the patterns of an old wives tale or urban legend. The piece has momentum and does lead the reader somewhere. For those like me who've never read Machado's fiction, this piece easily made me want to read more beguiling tales of women on the edge of reason.<br /><br />"Inventory" is one woman's diary of her sexual partners. The seventh entry in her little black book indicates that all may not be right with the world as an epidemic spreads from Northern California, impacting each of her subsequent entries. This is bar none the best piece. After the style choice of diary format gets familiar, there's an actual story here. Machado's writing is fraught with tension and put me on edge. I wanted to know more about the world that was developing and how her narrator would survive it. This piece had me sold that I had a great debut book on my hands.<br /><br />"Mothers" is about a woman whose bad romance (with a woman named Bad) culminates in her lover delivering a baby. It was not clear to me what the fuck was going on in this story. This is one of those pieces you discuss at book club, with everyone taking a turn describing what they think they read and together, you figure out what happened. Was there really a baby? Was the narrator really going crazy? What really happened in the house? Really? This sort of Writing is not for me and may not be for anyone who likes story and characters. Machado is also doing things in Capital Letters at this point. She seems to be trying too hard.<br /><br />"Especially Heinous (272 Views of <i>Law &amp; Order SVU</i>)" are little joke synopses of fake episodes of the long-running detective show. Apparently, Machado is a big time <i>SVU</i> fan and might have been compelled to write what she knows, but this is one most obnoxious things I've ever read in a book. A blog post or series of Tweets this dopey wouldn't have bothered me because social media and snark go hand in hand. As a fiction reader, though, I hate jokes. After three pages, I gave up and skipped to the next story, hoping that Machado might regain some quality control over the book. Not every pitch is going to be a strike ...<br /><br />"Real Women Have Bodies" is about a college grad working at a Forever 21 type store in a mall. She's seduced by a girl who supplies the retailer with women's garments and in a twist that gets the book back on track, women around the world are becoming non-corporeal, losing their mass. This piece comes closest to having story and characters and I did find myself becoming affected by the romance. The dark fantasy conceit isn't given priority and Machado is still too vague to be completely satisfying, but this was a decent piece.<br /><br />"Eight Bites" is about a woman who has a gastric-bypass type medical procedure and is sort of visited by the entity she shed. This conceit cannot hold the story built on top of it and on that basis, I checked out of it.<br /><br />"The Resident" is about a woman who drives into the mountains to take part in a funded fellowship for writers and artists so she can finish her novel. The residency also happens to be on the same lake she attended Girls Scouts camp at. Of course, the woman will experience strange things. Of course, the reader will wonder if what she's experiencing is real or has some Meaning. Of course, I hated this. <br /><br />"Difficult At Parties" is about a woman who experiencing some bad trauma coming home and trying to adjust. Her relationship with a man is as unclear as what happened to her or what she's experiencing. <br /><br /><i>Her Body and Other Parties</i> may be best recommended for those who enjoy writing, with lots of meaningful themes intentionally woven into them. I can't think of anything worse to spend my time reading. Maybe an alt-right manifesto. Some have described the book as "feminist," but I don't know what that means in terms of fiction. An author either creates a compelling story and characters, or she doesn't. There isn't a single piece in this book I'd want to tell someone about and for that reason, I can't recommend it. Machado errs on the side of obscurity, and errs a lot.</span>
  <a data-text-id="1167363182437560733" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<div id="review_2008830098" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2008830098" />
    <a title="Hannah" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/41788446-hannah"><img alt="Hannah" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1475256742p2/41788446.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2008830098?book_show_action=true">Nov 04, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Hannah" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Hannah" href="/user/show/41788446-hannah">Hannah</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/41788446-hannah?shelf=short-stories">short-stories</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/41788446-hannah?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2008830098" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer3514227120583547513">I was really looking forward to this book, ever since I saw a review by Roxane Gay for this; then when I read and loved one of these short stories earlier this year I was even more excited - and I was not disappointed in the least. I absolutely adored these stories and what Carmen Maria Machado has to offer. She writes just the kind of slightly unsettling and very upsetting short stories that I just adore. Her stories are twisted and mean but also beautiful beyond words. They have a core feminis</span>
  <span id="freeText3514227120583547513" style="display:none">I was really looking forward to this book, ever since I saw a review by Roxane Gay for this; then when I read and loved one of these short stories earlier this year I was even more excited - and I was not disappointed in the least. I absolutely adored these stories and what Carmen Maria Machado has to offer. She writes just the kind of slightly unsettling and very upsetting short stories that I just adore. Her stories are twisted and mean but also beautiful beyond words. They have a core feminist message while also being stylistically awesome and never losing sight of the humanity at the core of them. The stories are highly inventive, can be read both as a social commentary and often as love stories, her characters feel real and her language is precise and wonderful. <br /><br />As is usually the case I adored some stories more than others but overall this was a very strong collection and I can absolutely understand the praise it has garnered (it has been blurbed by Roxane Gay and Jeff VanderMeer among others). <br /><br />I loved "The Husband Stitch" (this is the story I had read before), maybe even more so the second time around: this inventive rumination on what secrets women are allowed to keep made me mad and sad at the same time.<br /><br />In "Inventory" a woman looks back on her past lovers as the world comes to an literal end around her. This story felt very different than the rest of the collection but I loved its wistful melancholy and the bleak surrounding Carmen Maria Machado evoked.<br /><br />My favourite of the bunch was the novella "Especially Heinous", written as short blurbs for a TV show (think "Law &amp; Order: Special Victims Unit" ) filled with ghosts with bells for eyes and doppelgängers that are eerily similar but very creepy. This story was unsettling and creepy but also packed an immense emotional punch.</span>
  <a data-text-id="3514227120583547513" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<div id="review_2146564228" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2146564228" />
    <a title="Simon" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/7232880-simon"><img alt="Simon" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467490736p2/7232880.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2146564228?book_show_action=true">Nov 12, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Simon" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Simon" href="/user/show/7232880-simon">Simon</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2146564228" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer16118609176210996744">A crazy sometimes conflicting collection of fabulist tales. When this collection works, on tales of women with ribbons on their bodies, sexual encounters during a world ending epidemic, women literally vanishing in their skin and people who can hear the inner thoughts of adult film stars when they are watching porn, it is amazing. But occasionally like with a twist on an America hit series and all it’s nine seasons of episodes or a tale of mothers that gets too other, it lost me a touch. That sa</span>
  <span id="freeText16118609176210996744" style="display:none">A crazy sometimes conflicting collection of fabulist tales. When this collection works, on tales of women with ribbons on their bodies, sexual encounters during a world ending epidemic, women literally vanishing in their skin and people who can hear the inner thoughts of adult film stars when they are watching porn, it is amazing. But occasionally like with a twist on an America hit series and all it’s nine seasons of episodes or a tale of mothers that gets too other, it lost me a touch. That said the brilliance won over. It’s a crazy, creepy, queer, quirky, fantastical, fabulist, sinister and sexual collection, read it.</span>
  <a data-text-id="16118609176210996744" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>

<div id="review_2184764471" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2184764471" />
    <a title="Mackenzi" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/7727874-mackenzi"><img alt="Mackenzi" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1512266700p2/7727874.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2184764471?book_show_action=true">Nov 14, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Mackenzi" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Mackenzi" href="/user/show/7727874-mackenzi">Mackenzi</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2184764471" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer2626736887476349753">*long keening noise only uttered in the shadow of a perfect book* </span>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">


<tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review2184764471">

    <div class="updateActionLinks">
        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link2184764471" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=2184764471&amp;resource_type=Review&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">flag</a>





      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2184764471'><a id="like_count_review_2184764471" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/2184764471?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">46 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>
&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a href="/review/show/2184764471?book_show_action=true&amp;from_review_page=1">see review</a>
    </div>


    <div id='comments_for_review_2184764471' style='display: none;'>
</div>

  </td>
</tr>

      </div>

  </div>

  <div class="clear"></div>
</div>

    </div>
  </div>
    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>



  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2090384475" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2090384475" />
    <a title="Blair" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/272909-blair"><img alt="Blair" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1493499323p2/272909.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2090384475?book_show_action=true">Aug 12, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Blair" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Blair" href="/user/show/272909-blair">Blair</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>

          <span class="greyText">&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;</span>
          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/36349639-her-body-and-other-parties">review of another edition</a>





          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/272909-blair?shelf=netgalley">netgalley</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/272909-blair?shelf=2017-release">2017-release</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/272909-blair?shelf=read-on-kindle">read-on-kindle</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/272909-blair?shelf=macabre-slipstream-weird">macabre-slipstream-weird</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/272909-blair?shelf=short-stories">short-stories</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/272909-blair?shelf=contemporary">contemporary</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2090384475" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer16361706304824990241">In her debut collection of short stories, Carmen Maria Machado mingles fabulism, body horror, erotica and feminist commentary. The thrust of <em>Her Body and Other Parties</em> is perhaps best encapsulated by the second story in the book, 'Inventory'. It starts with the narrator cataloguing everyone she's slept with, taking on that now-near-compulsory clinical tone, that Muumuu House type of thing of talking endlessly about sex but doing so in an affectless style that doesn't communicate any passion or j</span>
  <span id="freeText16361706304824990241" style="display:none">In her debut collection of short stories, Carmen Maria Machado mingles fabulism, body horror, erotica and feminist commentary. The thrust of <em>Her Body and Other Parties</em> is perhaps best encapsulated by the second story in the book, 'Inventory'. It starts with the narrator cataloguing everyone she's slept with, taking on that now-near-compulsory clinical tone, that Muumuu House type of thing of talking endlessly about sex but doing so in an affectless style that doesn't communicate any passion or joy or pleasure. It suddenly becomes more interesting when a hidden narrative emerges: as the narrator progresses through her later conquests, she talks of a pervasive virus, family members lost, a quarantine zone, evacuations and refugees. It's an unexpected approach to the dystopian theme and a pleasing subversion of first impressions, yet the story as a whole remains unsatisfying.<br /><br />Then there's the much-discussed and multi-award-nominated 'The Husband Stitch', a modern fable which updates the campfire tale 'The Green Ribbon'. Like the original, it is a horror story with a gruesome twist, but the true horrors here are ordinary ones: the husband's insistence that the wife have nothing of her own; the titular stitch itself. In striving for a fairytale flavour, Machado uses a mannered voice that renders her narrator smug and oddly prudish even as she recounts exhausting quantities of sex (a recurring motif, as you may already have guessed). I did enjoy her wry stage directions: 'If you are reading this story out loud, move aside the curtain to illustrate this final point to your listeners. It'll be raining, I promise.'<br /><br />Among the weaker stories is 'Especially Heinous', which reimagines plot summaries of <em>Law &amp; Order: Special Victims Unit</em> episodes through a surrealist lens, playing on the ubiquity of violence against women in such shows. This starts out as a cute absurdist gimmick, but it's about five times longer than it needs to be. Some images (the ghosts with bells for eyes; the grotesque secret of the dresses in 'Real Women Have Bodies') just don't make enough sense to work, much less shock. There's always an emptiness, something missing. (And there are so many instances of 'inside of' in these stories – inside of me, inside of her, inside of him, I swear it feels like every other paragraph in some stories. I wish an editor had taken their scalpel to those 'of's.)<br /><br />My favourite was 'The Resident'. While the subject matter is slightly more staid than some of the others – presumably semi-autobiographical in its portrait of a writer unravelling during a retreat – it's a relief that it isn't told at a cold, impersonal remove. It actually has heart and a personality, unlike so many of the others, and contains one of the few truly rousing scenes in the book, when the narrator lashes out at a patronising acquaintance and defends her right to write about 'crazy' heroines and madwomen in attics. This could be read as a manifesto for the collection as a whole (but isn't enough to save it). Also strong is 'Eight Bites', in which the weight the protagonist loses through bariatric surgery takes on a life of its own.<br /><br />It's difficult to articulate without sounding like an idiot who's missed the point entirely, but there's something I find so depressing about the kind of writing that's ostensibly feminist but seems to focus incessantly on the negatives of being a woman. In fiction such as this, the approach is often paired with candid-yet-detached writing about sex that I also find offputting (not to mention extremely unsexy). The stories are well-crafted and (when they don't feel workshopped to death) spark with strong ideas and entertaining metafictional touches, but <em>Her Body and Other Parties</em> didn't work for me the way I hoped it would.<br /><br />If you enjoyed this I'd recommend the following (all short story collections):<br /><em>
  <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/34958096.Things_We_Lost_in_the_Fire" title="Things We Lost in the Fire by Mariana Enríquez" rel="nofollow">Things We Lost in the Fire</a>
</em> by Mariana Enríquez <br /><em>
  <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/33807043.The_Doll_s_Alphabet" title="The Doll's Alphabet by Camilla Grudova" rel="nofollow">The Doll's Alphabet</a>
</em> by Camilla Grudova<br /><em>
  <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/28257667.Intimations_Stories" title="Intimations Stories by Alexandra Kleeman" rel="nofollow">Intimations</a>
</em> by Alexandra Kleeman<br /><em>
  <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/30079724.Homesick_for_Another_World" title="Homesick for Another World by Ottessa Moshfegh" rel="nofollow">Homesick for Another World</a>
</em> by Ottessa Moshfegh<br /><em>
  <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/30344265.The_Babysitter_at_Rest" title="The Babysitter at Rest by Jen George" rel="nofollow">The Babysitter at Rest</a>
</em> by Jen George<br /><br /><em>I received an advance review copy of</em> Her Body and Other Parties <em>from the publisher through <a href="http://www.netgalley.com/" rel="nofollow">NetGalley</a>.</em><br /><br /><a href="http://tinyletter.com/learnthisphrase" rel="nofollow">TinyLetter</a> | <a href="http://twitter.com/learnthisphrase" rel="nofollow">Twitter</a> | <a href="http://instagram.com/learnthisphrase" rel="nofollow">Instagram</a> | <a href="http://learnthisphrase.tumblr.com" rel="nofollow">Tumblr</a></span>
  <a data-text-id="16361706304824990241" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<div id="review_2123939473" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2123939473" />
    <a title="Elise (TheBookishActress)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/52545435-elise-thebookishactress"><img alt="Elise (TheBookishActress)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1539195408p2/52545435.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2123939473?book_show_action=true">Sep 14, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Elise (TheBookishActress)" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Elise (TheBookishActress)" href="/user/show/52545435-elise-thebookishactress">Elise (TheBookishActress)</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>



          <div>
    <span class="greyText">Recommended to Elise by: </span>
      <a href="/user/show/31211197-izzy">Izzy</a>
  </div>



          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=author-love">author-love</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=coverporn">coverporn</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=released-2017">released-2017</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=genre-contemporary">genre-contemporary</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=gorgeous-writing">gorgeous-writing</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=that-important-content">that-important-content</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=that-feminist-classic-energy">that-feminist-classic-energy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=that-lgbtq-rep-tho">that-lgbtq-rep-tho</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=that-rep-of-characters-of-color">that-rep-of-characters-of-color</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/52545435-elise-thebookishactress?shelf=short-story-collections">short-story-collections</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2123939473" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer10150989567116965581"><blockquote> <i>“I choose this life,” the prostitute says to the social worker. “I do. Please put your energy into helping girls who aren’t here by choice.” She is so right. She is murdered anyway.</i> </blockquote><br /><b>Strange, visceral, but altogether, just too confusing for me.</b><br /><br />I would recommend this to those who loved the metaphorical side of Roxane Gay’s <i>Difficult Women</i>. (Before you ask, I was not one of those people.) Because these stories... well, you’re not going to enjoy them unless you <i>get</i> them, at least partially. <br /><br />And to</span>
  <span id="freeText10150989567116965581" style="display:none"><blockquote>
  <i>“I choose this life,” the prostitute says to the social worker. “I do. Please put your energy into helping girls who aren’t here by choice.” She is so right. She is murdered anyway.</i>
</blockquote><br /><b>Strange, visceral, but altogether, just too confusing for me.</b><br /><br />I would recommend this to those who loved the metaphorical side of Roxane Gay’s <i>Difficult Women</i>. (Before you ask, I was not one of those people.) Because these stories... well, you’re not going to enjoy them unless you <i>get</i> them, at least partially. <br /><br />And to be quite honest, some of my disappointment was just plain <b>too-high expectations.</b> <i>The Husband Stitch</i> was the only Machado I’d read before, and I <i>adored</i> it. I expected something even better. It is the only five I gave within this collection. <br /><br />I feel like some asshole on twitter is going to find this book and decide to call everyone who didn’t get this a typical straight feminist or whatever, so to clarify: I’m a huge lesbian and the women kissing were not the confusing part. I really appreciated how unapologetically queer this collection is, and would definitely recommend it in my stack of great queer fiction. <br /><br />♔ <u>The Husband Stitch</u> - ★★★★★<br />I read this <i>twice</i> earlier due to <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2022000856" rel="nofollow">Melanie</a>'s awesome recommendation. This is a story about being consumed, losing your own agency, and how much you can give before you break. One thing is clear, though; <b>it's worth the read.</b> There were a few metaphors here I only understood on the second and third reads due to sheer exhaustion, which is really upsetting - I feel like this would be my fave story ever otherwise. You can read this story <a href="https://granta.com/the-husband-stitch/" rel="nofollow">here</a>. <br /><br />♚ <u>Inventory</u> - ★★★★☆<br />A story of a woman’s sex life as a plague destroys her world. Honestly, I don't even know what this was. Okay, I do; it’s an exploration of how sex alone can reflect an environment. There's this sort of raw quality to it, but I can't say it ever really got under my skin, and the character work could’ve been far stronger. <br /><br />♔ <u>Mothers</u> - ★★★★☆<br />No summary. Uhhh... somebody please explain what the hell this story's ending means? Because I honest to god do not understand. I think I kind of loved it, though. Maybe worth a reread. <br /><br />♚ <u>Especially Heinous</u> - ★★★☆☆<br />This is a slightly-too-long rundown of a series of Law and Order: SVU episodes. Using the real titles, Machado makes up an intriguing plot full of supernatural elements and twists. The ending of this worked perfectly for me, but the story itself was too long; twelve seasons is a lot of episodes and apparently, a lot of repetition. I got the point about dead prostitutes 30 pages in and at points it just kept going. Have to admit, though, that several of the episode descriptions will stay with me.<br /><br />♔ <u>Real Women Have Bodies</u> - ★★★★☆<br />This story is one of women who become translucent over time. I really appreciated it; the detail is visceral and the emotion raw. It <i>is</i> far more metaphorical than I tend to prefer, though. <br /><br />♚ <u>Eight Bites</u> - ★★★★☆<br />An exploration of disordered eating and fatphobia in society especially among women! and yet I also just didn’t fucking understand 75% of this, so?<br /><br />♔ <u>The Resident</u> - ★★★☆☆<br />This one is about confronting your past and all it comes with. The thematic conclusions are good, but unfortunately, I felt it was a bit overly long. <br /><br />♚ <u>Difficult at Parties</u> - ★★☆☆☆<br />I 👏 didn’t 👏 understand 👏 this 👏 at 👏 all 👏 what 👏 does 👏 it 👏 mean 👏<br /><br />ALL IN ALL: Good, but too metaphorical for my style and taste. I read one a night with <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2065859280" rel="nofollow">Melanie</a>and <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2183608097" rel="nofollow">Destiny</a>. <br /><br /><a href="http://thebookishactress.wordpress.com" rel="nofollow">Blog</a> | <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/52545435-elise-the-bookish-actress" rel="nofollow">Goodreads</a> | <a href="https://twitter.com/girladamparrish" rel="nofollow">Twitter</a> | <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVIY_GxZIuclzsIw9CLSe3g" rel="nofollow">Youtube</a></span>
  <a data-text-id="10150989567116965581" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>

  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2148442113" />
    <a title="Riley" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/23179211-riley"><img alt="Riley" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1504464829p2/23179211.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2148442113?book_show_action=true">Nov 14, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Riley" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Riley" href="/user/show/23179211-riley">Riley</a>

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2209918103" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2209918103" />
    <a title="Thomas" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2018505-thomas"><img alt="Thomas" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1463769552p2/2018505.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2209918103?book_show_action=true">Dec 10, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Thomas" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Thomas" href="/user/show/2018505-thomas">Thomas</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=feminism">feminism</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=short-stories-for-fun">short-stories-for-fun</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=lgbtq">lgbtq</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2018505-thomas?shelf=horror">horror</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2209918103" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer3569155259265366239"><b>3.5 stars</b><br /><br />A scintillating, sexually-charged short story collection that centers the emotions and experiences of queer women. Carmen Maria Machado writes about women's most pressing desires and their most difficult challenges. Almost all of the stories contain some element of fantasy or science fiction, such as women whose bodies disappear or a world that comes to an end because of a terrifying disease. Through these unique, uncomfortable narratives, Machado explores the pleasure and pain of women</span>
  <span id="freeText3569155259265366239" style="display:none"><b>3.5 stars</b><br /><br />A scintillating, sexually-charged short story collection that centers the emotions and experiences of queer women. Carmen Maria Machado writes about women's most pressing desires and their most difficult challenges. Almost all of the stories contain some element of fantasy or science fiction, such as women whose bodies disappear or a world that comes to an end because of a terrifying disease. Through these unique, uncomfortable narratives, Machado explores the pleasure and pain of women and their bodies, as well as the violence men often enact onto women's bodies. My favorite stories included "Eight Bites," which follows a woman who gets gastric bypass surgery and examines body image and self-esteem and how others influence our relationship with food, "The Husband Stitch," which interrogates male entitlement to women's bodies, and "Real Women Have Bodies," which explores a world in which women's bodies disappear and draws parallels to how society treats women and their bodies now.<br /><br />Overall, a genre-bending collection of stories that gives much-needed space to the narratives of queer women. I only detract from my rating because I struggled to connect with the characters in these stories aside from the three I named, as the fabulist or fantastical elements dominated the narrative or the narrative did not go on for long enough for me to feel invested (as often is the case with short stories). Still, I would recommend this collection to those interested in dark, sensual stories about women and their bodies.</span>
  <a data-text-id="3569155259265366239" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">


<tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review2209918103">
  <td colspan="2">
    <div class="updateActionLinks">
        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link2209918103" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=2209918103&amp;resource_type=Review&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">flag</a>





      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2209918103'><a id="like_count_review_2209918103" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/2209918103?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">35 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>
&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a href="/review/show/2209918103?book_show_action=true&amp;from_review_page=1">see review</a>
    </div>


    <div id='comments_for_review_2209918103' style='display: none;'>
<div class='brown_comment'>

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2183608097" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2183608097" />
    <a title="destiny ♎ [howling libraries]" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/15335689-destiny-howling-libraries"><img alt="destiny ♎ [howling libraries]" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1514747508p2/15335689.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2183608097?book_show_action=true">Nov 27, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="destiny ♎ [howling libraries]" class="user" itemprop="url" name="destiny ♎ [howling libraries]" href="/user/show/15335689-destiny-howling-libraries">destiny ♎ [howling libraries]</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>



          <div>
    <span class="greyText">Recommended to destiny by: </span>
      <a href="/user/show/3030788-melanie">Melanie</a>
  </div>



          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/15335689-destiny-howling-libraries?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/15335689-destiny-howling-libraries?shelf=horror">horror</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/15335689-destiny-howling-libraries?shelf=anthology">anthology</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/15335689-destiny-howling-libraries?shelf=lgbtqiap">lgbtqiap</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/15335689-destiny-howling-libraries?shelf=diverse-reads">diverse-reads</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/15335689-destiny-howling-libraries?shelf=owned-physical">owned-physical</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2183608097" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer17908715981608890147"><blockquote> <i>I have heard all of the stories about girls like me, and I am unafraid to make more of them.</i> </blockquote><br />This anthology isn't so much a collection of stories as it is a collection of <i>experiences.</i> Carmen Maria Machado writes beautifully; her voice is so incredibly unique, and no matter the content of the tale, she transports you right into the scene - for better or for worse. I'll do my best to give you my thoughts on each story, but at the end of the day, this is the sort of collection that I highly recomm</span>
  <span id="freeText17908715981608890147" style="display:none"><blockquote>
  <i>I have heard all of the stories about girls like me, and I am unafraid to make more of them.</i>
</blockquote><br />This anthology isn't so much a collection of stories as it is a collection of <i>experiences.</i> Carmen Maria Machado writes beautifully; her voice is so incredibly unique, and no matter the content of the tale, she transports you right into the scene - for better or for worse. I'll do my best to give you my thoughts on each story, but at the end of the day, this is the sort of collection that I highly recommend you simply pick up for yourself.<br /><br />→ <b>
  <i>The Husband Stitch</i>
</b> ★★★★★ ←<br />The anthology opens with a peculiar retelling of a classic horror legend: the woman with the ribbon around her throat, if you're familiar. The narrator carries us through her life: through meeting her significant other, wedding him, giving birth, the woes and beauties of motherhood, and more.<br /><br />She explores the paradox of being a woman who is proud of embracing her sexuality, while still, at times, noting the shame that society places upon her for it. She portrays the struggle of motherhood, and trying to do one's best despite all of the many obstacles that may cross a mother's path. Most of all, she explores feminism, and the fact that a woman, no matter how much she loves her partner or her child(ren), remains her own property at the end of the day. When a woman allows another human being to claim "ownership" of her, she loses herself.<br /><br /><blockquote>
  <i>"Why do you want to hide it from me?"<br />"I'm not hiding it. It just isn't yours."</i>
</blockquote><br />→ <b>
  <i>Inventory</i>
</b> ★★★★☆ ←<br />While the first story is metaphorical, the second story is literally an "inventory", or a history, of the narrator's sexual partners and relationships. This entry to the collection is incredibly explicit, but woven into the stories, we learn of a world coming to a halt, and an apocalyptic reality setting into place thanks to an unstoppable disease. Machado builds up a lovely but inescapable sense of impending dread.<br /><br />→ <b>
  <i>Mothers</i>
</b> ★★★☆☆ ←<br />The third entry begins with our narrator being handed a baby created by herself and her former female lover, and frankly, beyond this point, the rest of the story is a combination of beautiful, poetic narrative, and absolute chaos in the form of one of the most genuinely unreliable narrators I've ever read. If you enjoy unreliable narration and being left to piece things together for yourself, this will be right up your alley, but it was just a little too blurry and grey of an ending for my taste. One thing I will give Machado the utmost credit for in this story, though, is the incredible way she writes an abusive relationship. There were so many lines that were brutally familiar, but so cathartic, because they felt so raw and genuinely.<br /><br /><blockquote>
  <i>There was no way for me to tell her that we are so close, we are so close, please don't do this now, we are so fucking close.</i>
</blockquote><br />→ <b>
  <i>Especially Heinous</i>
</b> ★★☆☆☆ ←<br />This was my least favorite entry in the collection, though that doesn't mean it was <i>bad.</i> This one details an alternate universe of <i>Law &amp; Order: SVU</i> in which there are ghosts of dead prostitutes with bells for eyes, doppelgangers dead-set on ruining lives, affairs, lost memories, and a character falling somewhere between mentally unwell and possessed. It follows several "seasons", with each "episode"'s synopsis ranging from a sentence to a paragraph. It was actually an incredibly unique idea, and I loved the metaphors being presented, but it overstayed its welcome and I found myself drudging through the last several pages.<br /><br />→ <b>
  <i>Real Women Have Bodies</i>
</b> ★★★★☆ ←<br />Out of all of the stories, this was the toughest for me to rate, because I felt like it could be interpreted so many different ways, and I found myself second-guessing what it meant to <i>me.</i> Our narrator, a dress shop employee, lives in a world where women keep disappearing. They don't vanish into thin air; instead, they simply wake up one day to find their bodies fading, until they become translucent, and then are gone for good. At first, I believed it to be a commentary on society's expectations of women in general, but at one point, the story explains that women are fading younger and younger, and suddenly, I was reading a story about a world in which women lose their value as they lose their youth, and their worth is "lost" earlier with each passing generation. Sounds familiar, doesn't it?<br /><br /><blockquote>
  <i>Soon, I'll be nothing more, too. None of us will make it to the end.</i>
</blockquote><br />→ <b>
  <i>Eight Bites</i>
</b> ★★★★★ ←<br />As someone who has struggled with disordered eating, I have vowed to always be honest in my reviews, but to be especially candid when it comes to ED rep, because it so easily goes awry. Let me preface this first, though, by saying that I have never seen a representation of an eating disorder that is as raw, and authentic, and <i>flawless</i> as what I read in this short story. I felt like I was gasping for air at times. The story follows a woman who, after years of struggling with her weight, decides to have gastric surgery to assist her weight loss. She comes from a line of women who are "too large", and even reminisces on her mother's disordered habits from her youth, though she doesn't seem to grasp how her self-loathing has alienated her own overweight daughter, too. What follows her surgery is brutal, and familiar, and heartbreaking, and so cathartic.<br /><br /><blockquote>
  <i>"You are unwanted," I say.</i>
</blockquote><br />→ <b>
  <i>The Resident</i>
</b> ★★★★☆ ←<br />This was another tough one to rate, because it felt so incredibly personal; I literally, at multiple times, thought, "Am I reading an autobiography?" It tells the story of a writer who goes to a writer's retreat in an area where she once had a childhood "incident" with her Girl Scouts group, but we are left guessing as to what the incident was for most of the tale. In a nutshell, it's a story of learning to accept who you are and how you feel about yourself, as well as the world around you.<br /><br /><blockquote>
  <i>"Do you ever listen to yourself? This is crazy, that is crazy, everything is crazy to you. By whose measure?"</i>
</blockquote><br />→ <b>
  <i>Difficult At Parties</i>
</b> ★★★★☆ ←<br />Machado rounds out the ending of the book with a story about a woman who has suffered sexual assault and is trying to find her place in the world again with her new traumas. She wades through the police search for her attacker, as well as desperate attempts to become intimate with her lover once more, and ends up seeking comfort in pornographic films. This is a bizarre, <i>tough</i> read, but it's important, and like every other story in this collection, it painted a scene that served as a reminder of just how brutal life can be for women in this world.<br /><br />→ <b>
  <i>final thoughts &amp; rating</i>
</b> ★★★★☆ ←<br />If I average everything up, I only actually gave this collection 3.88/5 stars, but overall, it felt like a 4- or even 4.5-star read. It is unapologetically feminist, queer, candid, and authentic. It is brutal at times, cathartic at others, and most of all, it is <i>
  <b>important.</b>
</i> Be aware that it comes with nearly every trigger warning I can think of, but do yourself a favor and pick up a copy.</span>
  <a data-text-id="17908715981608890147" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>

<div id="review_2019515902" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2019515902" />
    <a title="Justin Tate" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/23082940-justin-tate"><img alt="Justin Tate" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1483163608p2/23082940.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2019515902?book_show_action=true">Jun 04, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Justin Tate" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Justin Tate" href="/user/show/23082940-justin-tate">Justin Tate</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2019515902" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer16476307000180744920">Let me first say that Carmen Maria Machado is a brilliant writer. All throughout this book I was in awe of her use of language. She's also a visionary. These stories are imaginative, original, and intriguing in ways that far exceed the typical literary output of Iowa graduates.<br /><p></p><br />That being said, the actual storytelling is a mixed bag ranging from flawless to awkward. Many feel bloated, full of content that's unrelated to the general scope of the story. This is probably why the stories are all hard</span>
  <span id="freeText16476307000180744920" style="display:none">Let me first say that Carmen Maria Machado is a brilliant writer. All throughout this book I was in awe of her use of language. She's also a visionary. These stories are imaginative, original, and intriguing in ways that far exceed the typical literary output of Iowa graduates.<br /><p></p><br />That being said, the actual storytelling is a mixed bag ranging from flawless to awkward. Many feel bloated, full of content that's unrelated to the general scope of the story. This is probably why the stories are all hard to categorize. Too long to be a standard short story, but too underdeveloped to be a novella or even novelette. Her characters also seem to all be manifestations of an "author" persona, or narrator voice, rather than real people.<br /><br />Here's how I rated each story individually:<br /><br /><b>The Husband Stitch</b> - 5/5 - AMAZING. A must-read. Every word counts and every word hypnotizes. <br /><b>Inventory</b> - 4/5 - A solid follow-up to the blockbuster opening story.<br /><b>Mothers</b> - 3/5<br /><b>Especially Heinous</b> - 3/5 - This is a fictionalized version of Law &amp; Order episodes. Having not seen the show I felt on the outside of an inside joke. Probably more amusing for fans of the show.<br /><b>Real Women Have Bodies</b> - 4/5 <br /><b>Eight Bites</b> - 4/5<br /><b>The Resident</b> - 2/5<br /><b>Difficult at Parties</b> - 2/5</span>
  <a data-text-id="16476307000180744920" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>

<div id="review_2105574217" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2105574217" />
    <a title="Coleen (The Book Ramblings)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/8168714-coleen-the-book-ramblings"><img alt="Coleen (The Book Ramblings)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1424634166p2/8168714.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2105574217?book_show_action=true">Oct 13, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Coleen (The Book Ramblings)" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Coleen (The Book Ramblings)" href="/user/show/8168714-coleen-the-book-ramblings">Coleen (The Book Ramblings)</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/8168714-coleen-the-book-ramblings?shelf=anthologies-shortstories">anthologies-shortstories</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/8168714-coleen-the-book-ramblings?shelf=2017">2017</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2105574217" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer15186995491270827690">Her Body and Other Parties is a riveting 8-story collection that is a gritty, provocative debut. It’s a fusion of magical realism, horror, supernatural and fantasy that focuses on women’s lives and their bodies. In general, I am not fond of short story collections, but this is outstanding work. After each story, I had to take the time to process it, because they really make you think and view the world in a new perspective. <br /><br />It’s an original and electric collection of stories that I thoroughly en</span>
  <span id="freeText15186995491270827690" style="display:none">Her Body and Other Parties is a riveting 8-story collection that is a gritty, provocative debut. It’s a fusion of magical realism, horror, supernatural and fantasy that focuses on women’s lives and their bodies. In general, I am not fond of short story collections, but this is outstanding work. After each story, I had to take the time to process it, because they really make you think and view the world in a new perspective. <br /><br />It’s an original and electric collection of stories that I thoroughly enjoyed regardless of how disturbing some were because Machado’s storytelling is powerful, innovative, and like an otherworldly experience. You know when you discover an author’s work and realize it’s something you’ve been missing? Her Body and Other Parties is exactly that.<br /><br />The Husband Stitch — A retelling of the classic kid’s creepy story The Girl with the Ribbon Around Her Neck, where all women wear ribbons on some part of their body.<br />Inventory — A list of sexual encounters told as a virus spreads across the world.<br />Mothers — A disturbing, confusing tale about a woman who is given a baby by her lover who then leaves. It was difficult to depict what was real and what wasn’t in this. While strange and I didn’t quite comprehend it, I didn’t feel complied to because it was still intriguing.<br />Especially Heinous — A reimagining with a dark supernatural-magical realism take on every episode of SUV. As a fan of Law &amp; Order: SUV, I was interested in this novella, but it was the only story in the collection that I didn’t care to finish reading.<br />Real Women Have Bodies — A haunting story about women who become invisible.<br />Eight Bites — A narrator who has bariatric surgery and the sacrifice people make to be thin in today’s society, the impact it has on the mind and fellow females around us<br />The Resident — An author spends some time at an artist’s retreat, where things take a strange, disturbing turn.<br />Difficult at Parties — A look into a woman’s life after severe trauma and the aftermath when she starts to hear voices of actors in erotic films.<br /><br />As expected with short story collections, there were some I enjoyed more than others, and some in this collection weren’t easily understood, but they were thought-provoking. Due to that, some descriptions for the stories were not easy to explain without giving away the plot.</span>
  <a data-text-id="15186995491270827690" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2105574217'><a id="like_count_review_2105574217" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/2105574217?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">29 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>
&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a href="/review/show/2105574217?book_show_action=true&amp;from_review_page=1">see review</a>
    </div>
