  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2164920178" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2164920178" />
    <a title="Krista Regester" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/53724042-krista-regester"><img alt="Krista Regester" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1513445380p2/53724042.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2164920178?book_show_action=true">Oct 26, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Krista Regester" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Krista Regester" href="/user/show/53724042-krista-regester">Krista Regester</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2164920178" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer17852791883299671874"><b>The Husband Stitch</b> 5 stars, A tale of tales, spinning old folk stories throughout one important one. How much can one possibly give to someone before it's too much? This was beautifully written. <br /><br /><b>Inventory</b> 5 stars, This was haunting and unique. An apocalyptic story told through each of the narrator's sexual experiences. <br /><br /><b>Mothers</b> 3 stars, I'm still a tad perplexed by this one. I wanted to find a clear plot but maybe that's where I went wrong. It was obvious that the narrator was experiencing a hear</span>
  <span id="freeText17852791883299671874" style="display:none"><b>The Husband Stitch</b> 5 stars, A tale of tales, spinning old folk stories throughout one important one. How much can one possibly give to someone before it's too much? This was beautifully written. <br /><br /><b>Inventory</b> 5 stars, This was haunting and unique. An apocalyptic story told through each of the narrator's sexual experiences. <br /><br /><b>Mothers</b> 3 stars, I'm still a tad perplexed by this one. I wanted to find a clear plot but maybe that's where I went wrong. It was obvious that the narrator was experiencing a heartbreak that had left her vulnerable and wounded - but I still had many questions when it ended. <br /><br /><b>Especially Heinous</b> 2 stars, This was not for me. I still have NO clue what happened here. This was other worldly in a confusing way. 272 little blurbs that really never formed a clear story! I found myself skipping through these hoping to dear god that I wouldn't hear Benson or Stabler's names one more time. This could have been a cool idea but it didn't carry over well, especially in audio book format. I couldn't tell if a new story had started or if the same one was still going!<br /><br /><b>Real Women Have Bodies</b> 4 stars, I don't know how Carmen Maria Machado comes up with these incredible ideas! This was raw, broken, and disturbing. The idea of just slowly fading away and not having control over your body, is terrifying.<br /><br /><b>Eight Bites</b> 3 stars, I think that deciding to modify your body in anyway is an extremely difficult and personal decision. So.. why was she so worried about everyone's opinion on the matter?! The ending was the best part and I almost wish that could have been more of the focus of the story. <br /><br /><b>The Resident</b> 3 stars, There was some really good imagery in this one, but it kind of fell flat for me. <br /><br /><b>Difficult At Parties</b> 5 stars, Don't we all want to know what everyone else is thinking? How about during sex? Ahh yes please.</span>
  <a data-text-id="17852791883299671874" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2164920178'><a id="like_count_review_2164920178" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/2164920178?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">32 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>

    <div id='comments_for_review_2164920178' style='display: none;'>

    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>



  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2344479630" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2344479630" />
    <a title="Paul Fulcher" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3250759-paul-fulcher"><img alt="Paul Fulcher" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1365030378p2/3250759.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2344479630?book_show_action=true">Mar 30, 2018</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Paul Fulcher" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Paul Fulcher" href="/user/show/3250759-paul-fulcher">Paul Fulcher</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>

          <span class="greyText">&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;</span>
          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781781259528" href="/book/show/36934018-her-body-and-other-parties">review of another edition</a>





          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3250759-paul-fulcher?shelf=2018">2018</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2344479630" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer6375070543981841371"><i>What’s worse - writing a trope or being one. What about being more than one.</i><br /><br />Her Body and Other Parties is a striking collection of short fiction - uneven but at its best quite brilliant (and at its worst - the tedious novella Especially Heinous - best skipped altogether unless you are a fan of the US TV series on which it is apparently based).<br /><br />A deliberate mash-up of genres - supernatural, horror, erotic, folklore, comedy, LGBTQ, feminist: Machado explains [1]<i>I’m really interested in interrogatin</i></span>
  <span id="freeText6375070543981841371" style="display:none"><i>What’s worse - writing a trope or being one. What about being more than one.</i><br /><br />Her Body and Other Parties is a striking collection of short fiction - uneven but at its best quite brilliant (and at its worst - the tedious novella Especially Heinous - best skipped altogether unless you are a fan of the US TV series on which it is apparently based).<br /><br />A deliberate mash-up of genres - supernatural, horror, erotic, folklore, comedy, LGBTQ, feminist: Machado explains [1]<i>I’m really interested in interrogating tropes and engaging with genres and messing with them in a way I find satisfying.</i> Perhaps the most obvious literary antecedents are Angela Carter and Shirley Jackson - although Machado only read the latter when her she found people comparing their work, albeit she would now acknowledge that reading her has influenced her later stories. Machado herself has said [2]: <i>My influences are pretty wide-ranging. Some are obvious: Kelly Link, Karen Russell, Shirley Jackson, Angela Carter, Helen Oyeyemi. Some are set a little deeper in my past: Ray Bradbury, Lois Duncan, John Bellairs, Louis Sachar, Roald Dahl, Gabriel García Márquez.</i><br /><br />The overall effect was very similar, albeit a lot more explicitly sexual, to Camilla Grudova's Doll's Alphabet, (my review <a target="_blank" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2244596471" rel="nofollow">https://www.goodreads.com/review/show...</a>) which was a more consistent and perhaps slightly better book, but if you like one I would strongly recommend the other.<br /><br />The two stand out stories for me were The Husband Stitch and The Resident, both of which have meta-fictional elements that stand as commentary on Machado's wider project.<br /><br />The Resident sees the narrator, an author, attending an artist's retreat to work on her novel, in a remote area by a lake where, as a child, she had attended Brownie camp and had her first experience of kissing another girl. When she shares her novel-in-progress with her fellow artists, she gets a negative reaction from one of them, the overly-conventional Lydia:<br /><br /><i>“Do you ever worry about writing the madwoman-in-the-attic story?”<br /><br />“I’m afraid I don’t know what you mean.”<br /><br />“You know. That old trope. Writing a story where the female protagonist is utterly batty. It’s sort of tiresome and regressive and, well, done”—here she gesticulated so forcefully that a few drops of red spattered the tablecloth—“don’t you think? And the mad lesbian, isn’t that a stereotype as well? Do you ever wonder about that?”</i><br /><br />the narrator goes on to respond:<br /><br /><i>“She isn’t batty or mad, she’s just - she’s just a nervous character.”<br /><br />“I’ve never known anyone like that,” Lydia said. <br /><br />“She’s me,” I clarified, “More or less. She’s just in her head a lot.”</i><br /><br />And then, in a deliberate authorial swipe at the reception to (not the quality of) Knausgaard's work, one echoed by Rachel Cusk in Kudos: <i>"Men are permitted to write concealed autobiography, but I cannot do the same? It’s ego if I do it?”</i><br /><br />In a later scene she reflects: <i>What’s worse - writing a trope or being one. What about being more than one.</i><br /><br />And the spooky element of the story draws brilliantly on the frankly rather disturbing-in-its-own-right foundation story of The Brownies [3]<br /><br /><i>Twist me and turn me and show me the elf, I looked in the water and there saw ….....</i><br /><br />Machado has said that her early inspiration included spooky tales told around the campfire, and her ability to take existing fairystories and urban myths and give them a twist of her own in showcased quite brilliantly in the opening story The Husband Stitch.<br /><br /><i>Anything could move out there in the darkness, I think. A hook-handed man. A ghostly hitch-hiker repeating her journey. An old woman summoned from the rest of her mirror by the chants of children. Everyone knows these stories – that is, everyone tells them – but no one ever believes them.<br /><br />His eyes drift over the water, and then land on my neck.<br /><br />– Tell me about your ribbon, he says.<br />– There is nothing to tell. It’s my ribbon.<br />– May I touch it?<br />– No.<br />– I want to touch it, he says.<br />– No.</i><br /><br />This one combines the oft-told story of the girl with a ribbon round her neck (e.g. the Green Ribbon version in <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/108538.In_a_Dark__Dark_Room_and_Other_Scary_Stories" title="In a Dark, Dark Room and Other Scary Stories by Alvin Schwartz" rel="nofollow">In a Dark, Dark Room and Other Scary Stories</a>) with the urban-myth - or perhaps not a myth [4] - of the post-partum 'husband stitch'. <br /><br />But Machado works many-many more such horror-tales and urban myths into her story, quite explicitly, for example:<br /><br /><i>When I select my wedding gown, I am reminded of the story of the young woman who wished to go to a dance with her lover, but could not afford a dress. She purchased a lovely white frock from a secondhand shop, and then later fell ill and passed from this earth. The coroner who performed her autopsy discovered she had died from exposure to embalming fluid. It turned out that an unscrupulous undertaker’s assistant had stolen the dress from the corpse of a bride.<br /><br />The moral of that story, I think, is that being poor will kill you. Or perhaps the moral is that brides never fare well in stories, and one should avoid either being a bride, or being in a story. After all, stories can sense happiness and snuff it out like a candle.</i><br /><br />And she includes some suggested effects for reading the story which starts relatively conventionally, albeit with implicit social commentary:<br /><br /><i>(If you read this story out loud, please use the following voices:<br />Me: as a child, high-pitched, forgettable; as a woman, the same.<br />The boy who will grow into a man, and be my spouse: robust with his own good fortune.)</i><br /><br />and become increasingly bizarre:<br /><br /><i>(If you are reading this story out loud, force a listener to reveal a secret, then open the nearest window to the street and scream it as loudly as you are able.)</i><br /><br />Unfortunately the collection is a little marred by the longest piece Especially Heinous: 272 Views of Law &amp; Order: SUV which I would suggest skipping entirely.<br /><br />It consists of 272 entries of precis for a trashy TV homicide series, for example the first:<br /><br /><i><b>“Payback”</b>: Stabler and Benson investigate the murder and castration of a New York City cab driver. They discover that the victim assumed the identity of another man years before because he was wanted by police. In the end, Stabler discovers that the stolen identity of the man in question was also stolen, and he and Benson have to begin the investigation all over again. That night, as he unsuccessfully tries to sleep, Stabler begins to hear a strange noise. A deep drumming, two beats. It seems like it’s coming from his basement. When he investigates the basement, it sounds like it’s coming from outside.</i><br /><br />From other reviews I learned that Law and Order: SVU is an actual US TV series (who watches this stuff?) and it seems episodes in name and, loosely in terms of certain characters and plot developments, follow those of the series. In practice, it seems hard to satirise something that is already beyond satire - for example the actual precis for Payback:<br /><br /><i>In the episode, the detectives of the Special Victims Unit investigate a taxi-cab driver's brutal murder and castration. Detective Olivia Benson becomes personally involved in the case after discovering that the taxi driver was a rapist and murderer himself.</i><br /><br />Which presumably makes this great fun fans of the TV programme but certainly makes it rather a waste of time for people who have never heard of it. The 272 views are at least 262 too many.<br /><br />But overall, recommended if uneven - 3.5 stars.<br /><br />Sources:<br /><br />[1] <a target="_blank" href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/jan/07/carmen-maria-machado-meet-the-author-fiction-interview" rel="nofollow">https://www.theguardian.com/books/201...</a><br /><br />[2] <a target="_blank" href="https://mastersreview.com/interview-carmen-maria-machado/" rel="nofollow">https://mastersreview.com/interview-c...</a><br /><br />[3] <a target="_blank" href="https://www.girlguiding.org.uk/what-we-do/brownies-7-10/im-a-brownie/the-brownie-story/" rel="nofollow">https://www.girlguiding.org.uk/what-w...</a><br /><br />[4] <a target="_blank" href="https://www.healthline.com/health-news/husband-stitch-is-not-just-myth#1" rel="nofollow">https://www.healthline.com/health-new...</a>)<br /><br />[5] <a target="_blank" href="https://carmenmariamachado.com/fiction/" rel="nofollow">https://carmenmariamachado.com/fiction/</a> (for many of the stories in their original forms, as well as others]</span>
  <a data-text-id="6375070543981841371" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2190361417" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2190361417" />
    <a title="Trudie" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4617856-trudie"><img alt="Trudie" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1498473572p2/4617856.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2190361417?book_show_action=true">Jan 27, 2018</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Trudie" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Trudie" href="/user/show/4617856-trudie">Trudie</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4617856-trudie?shelf=tob18">tob18</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4617856-trudie?shelf=powells-indiespensible">powells-indiespensible</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4617856-trudie?shelf=read-2018">read-2018</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4617856-trudie?shelf=short-stories-novella">short-stories-novella</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4617856-trudie?shelf=other-awards">other-awards</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4617856-trudie?shelf=5-star-reads">5-star-reads</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4617856-trudie?shelf=best-of-2018">best-of-2018</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4617856-trudie?shelf=indiebuddyreads">indiebuddyreads</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2190361417" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer4239968850832869763">Going into this I was not at all sure I would enjoy it. Novels generally appeal to me rather than a short story collection and anything labelled fabulist or absurdist has me wary. However, I am always pleased to find my preconceptions proved wrong. Within a few pages I knew I loved this. Machado's writing is electric, unapologetically weird and visceral while also feeling on point with the current #MeToo zeitegist.<br /><br />This is essentially a collection of contemporary fairy tales, the same sense of cr</span>
  <span id="freeText4239968850832869763" style="display:none">Going into this I was not at all sure I would enjoy it. Novels generally appeal to me rather than a short story collection and anything labelled fabulist or absurdist has me wary. However, I am always pleased to find my preconceptions proved wrong. Within a few pages I knew I loved this. Machado's writing is electric, unapologetically weird and visceral while also feeling on point with the current #MeToo zeitegist.<br /><br />This is essentially a collection of contemporary fairy tales, the same sense of creepy, inexplicable horror that I get from reading Grimm's stories also seeps out from these pages. Yet the sex in these tales, unlike Grimm, is frank, wild and at times explicit. These stories really grab you up, spin you around and spit you back out. I loved the experience, though I doubt it is a collection for everyone.<br /><br />Three stories in particular lodged in my brain. The first story, <i> The Husband Stitch </i> is arguably the best of the collection. It comes hurtling at you, deliciously subversive, unapologetically sexual and dark. It jolted me awake and I was ready for more. <i>The Mothers </i> and <i>Especially Heinous </i> both frustrated me at first, mostly as I had no idea what was going on. But Machado's use of language is so absorbing, things are tantalising eluded to but not made explicit. Like Sherlock Holmes I found myself combing back over the story searching for clues and joining my own threads of meaning together. <br /><br />I am really quite taken with this author and her short story collection. The writing, which I concede could be polarising for some, feels fresh, lively and bold. It is surreal and layered and yet still rooted in the requirement (at least for me) to tell a good story.<br />If this is a debut offering I am first in line for whatever else Machado decides to write.</span>
  <a data-text-id="4239968850832869763" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2171528220" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2171528220" />
    <a title="Meike" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/59050228-meike"><img alt="Meike" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1514995700p2/59050228.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2171528220?book_show_action=true">Nov 15, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Meike" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Meike" href="/user/show/59050228-meike">Meike</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/59050228-meike?shelf=usa">usa</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/59050228-meike?shelf=2017-read">2017-read</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2171528220" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer9319661847252331612"><b>Winner of the National Book Critics Circle John Leonard Award for Best First Book 2017</b> <br />It's true that Machado managed to write unusual, poetic and multi-dimensional short stories about the female body - she twists and turns a classic format, throwing in a little horror, sci-fi, some urban legends, and lots of pyschology and sex. She is an expert when it comes to creating atmosphere, and she can also be quite funny (it seems to be a minority opinion, but I thought her haunted re-telling of "Law &</span>
  <span id="freeText9319661847252331612" style="display:none"><b>Winner of the National Book Critics Circle John Leonard Award for Best First Book 2017</b> <br />It's true that Machado managed to write unusual, poetic and multi-dimensional short stories about the female body - she twists and turns a classic format, throwing in a little horror, sci-fi, some urban legends, and lots of pyschology and sex. She is an expert when it comes to creating atmosphere, and she can also be quite funny (it seems to be a minority opinion, but I thought her haunted re-telling of "Law &amp; Order: SVU" was hilarious, effectively mocking the inherent clichés of the original format). <br /><br />What bothered me a little about this collection could well be a matter of personal taste: There are parts of some stories and even a whole story ("Mothers") that are so open to interpretation that the result is a breakdown of communication between Machado and me. Or to put it differently: I am assuming that an author tries to communicate something to his or her readers, and even though I have no problem with this message being ambiguous (in fact, I want my books to be challenging), I don't enjoy texts that are so open to interpretation that one might find 20 potential meanings - I tend to get bored with symbols and allusions that are so rich that they are borderline random. <br /><br />Nevertheless, I am really happy that I read this, because Machado's voice is different, unique, and deserves to be heard - so thanks to Will for encouraging me to pick up this book, and thanks to Tim and Julia for lending me their copy! :-)</span>
  <a data-text-id="9319661847252331612" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">


<tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review2171528220">
  <td colspan="2">
    <div class="updateActionLinks">
        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link2171528220" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flagged/new?resource_id=2171528220&amp;resource_type=Review&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">flag</a>





      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2171528220'><a id="like_count_review_2171528220" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/2171528220?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">24 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2234188654" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2234188654" />
    <a title="Alex" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3144945-alex"><img alt="Alex" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1303883046p2/3144945.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2234188654?book_show_action=true">Mar 01, 2018</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Alex" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Alex" href="/user/show/3144945-alex">Alex</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>


          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>
           <span class="uitext reviewText">readers of erotic law &amp; order fan fiction</span></div>




          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3144945-alex?shelf=best-of-2017">best-of-2017</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3144945-alex?shelf=smut">smut</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3144945-alex?shelf=2018">2018</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2234188654" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer14373096530712933339"><i>I kicked off 2018 by reading some of the best of 2017. Here's <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/list/3144945-alex?shelf=best-of-2017" rel="nofollow">my list;</a> here's <a href="http://digg.com/2017/best-books-2017-lists-sing-unburied-sing-lincoln-in-the-bardo" rel="nofollow">Digg's aggregate top ten</a> list.</i><br><br>"All the Hooters waitresses get pregnant at once. No one will say why. 'This is not really a case,' Benson says, exasperated."<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1519954604ra/25146521.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I'm sorry, that gif is just going to be there blinking until you scroll past it or something, but it was also blinking in my head during the centerpiece of this short story collection, which is called "Especially Heinous" and told entirely through capsule descriptio</span>
  <span id="freeText14373096530712933339" style="display:none"><i>I kicked off 2018 by reading some of the best of 2017. Here's <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/list/3144945-alex?shelf=best-of-2017" rel="nofollow">my list;</a> here's <a href="http://digg.com/2017/best-books-2017-lists-sing-unburied-sing-lincoln-in-the-bardo" rel="nofollow">Digg's aggregate top ten</a> list.</i><br><br>"All the Hooters waitresses get pregnant at once. No one will say why. 'This is not really a case,' Benson says, exasperated."<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1519954604ra/25146521.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I'm sorry, that gif is just going to be there blinking until you scroll past it or something, but it was also blinking in my head during the centerpiece of this short story collection, which is called "Especially Heinous" and told entirely through capsule descriptions of episodes of Law &amp; Order: Special Victims Unit. My ex used to watch this show for hours upon hours, and I was always a little creeped out by the whole thing. It seems lurid, doesn't it? "Now with especial heinousness!" Carmen Maria Machado agrees with me but also with my ex. The story follows Stabler and Benson, who are these two<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1519954857i/25146535._SX540_.jpg" alt="benson_stabler" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>(I had to look it up and I'm sure this whole thing would have been even better for me if hundreds of in-jokes weren't flying over my head) as they try to deny their lust for each other. Benson is haunted by dead, raped underage models with bells for eyes. A pair of doppelgangers appear, Abler and Henson. Copycats? I don't know. The thing with women is that they're always getting raped, is sortof the feeling you get from the show, which, actually, is not entirely as untrue as you would like it to be, and it is - what's the phrase I'm looking for - especially heinous.<br><br>It works an awful lot better than you'd think it would, which I mean you'd think it wouldn't work at all - it's just 272 fake episodes of Law &amp; Order: SVU! How can that not be an annoying disaster? It isn't, but my favorite is the <i>other</i> novella here, "The Resident," a Gothic set at an artists' retreat in the woods that manages to mash up references to madwomen in attics, grotesque body horror (oozing cysts!) and maybe a Fatal Attraction riff? I don't know but that bunny is dead. If Machado is planning on expanding something into a novel, as one does, it ought to be this one and she's onto something.<br><br>She's onto something generally. There's a lot of mashing up going on in art these days, so to find Machado throwing <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1424027954" title="My brief review" rel="nofollow">Angela Carter</a> in a bucket with internet porn makes sense. "It is my right to reside in my own mind," says the narrator of The Resident. Machado's mind is dangerous and brilliant.<br><br>"Benson accidentally catches a rapist when she Google-stalks her newest OKCupid date. She can't decide whether to mark this in the 'success' ('caught rapist') or 'failure' ('date didn't work out') column. She marks it in both."</span>
  <a data-text-id="14373096530712933339" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2234188654'><a id="like_count_review_2234188654" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/2234188654?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">22 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F33375622-her-body-and-other-parties">Like</a></span>

<div id="review_2205718282" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2205718282" />
    <a title="Julie Zantopoulos" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/51094260-julie-zantopoulos"><img alt="Julie Zantopoulos" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1503178209p2/51094260.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2205718282?book_show_action=true">Feb 13, 2018</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Julie Zantopoulos" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Julie Zantopoulos" href="/user/show/51094260-julie-zantopoulos">Julie Zantopoulos</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/51094260-julie-zantopoulos?shelf=audiobook-reads">audiobook-reads</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/51094260-julie-zantopoulos?shelf=library-read">library-read</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/51094260-julie-zantopoulos?shelf=read-in-2018">read-in-2018</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2205718282" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer1826994724393613135">The Husband Stitch: 5 Stars this was my favorite of the book so far and a really impactful and hard-hitting start to this series of short stories. <br /><br />Inventory: 4 Stars- an interesting look at sex and sexuality in a dystopian type world. <br /><br />Mothers: 2 stars-too weird and convoluted for me to follow, honestly. <br /><br />Especially Heinous: 2 Stars- I don't watch Law &amp; Order and this was some strange Benson and Stabler re-write that just didn't connect with me. <br /><br />Real Women Have Bodies: 5 Stars- holy crap! The</span>
  <span id="freeText1826994724393613135" style="display:none">The Husband Stitch: 5 Stars this was my favorite of the book so far and a really impactful and hard-hitting start to this series of short stories. <br /><br />Inventory: 4 Stars- an interesting look at sex and sexuality in a dystopian type world. <br /><br />Mothers: 2 stars-too weird and convoluted for me to follow, honestly. <br /><br />Especially Heinous: 2 Stars- I don't watch Law &amp; Order and this was some strange Benson and Stabler re-write that just didn't connect with me. <br /><br />Real Women Have Bodies: 5 Stars- holy crap! The idea that women fight to be seen, to have identities outside of their physical appearance and sometimes feel unseen, invisible, was so powerful. <br /><br />Eight Bites: 5 Stars- Oh man, this was heartbreaking and horrible to read. The idea of surgery and body image issues passed down through generations and peers. The hate you hold for your body and what you'll do to maintain the kind of body you think you should have. The heartbreak of a daughter wondering if her body is wrong because her mother didn't like her own is so raw, so real. <br /><br />The Resident: 2 stars- meh, this one didn't connect with me and was pretty forgettable. <br /><br />Difficult At Parties &amp; Closing: 4 Stars, this was a really poignant story that really packed an emotional punch. This collection started and ended really strong and left me with a lot to think about. I do think that I'd have appreciated it even more had I read the physical version and not listened to it...however, I want to point out that the audiobook was FANTASTICALLY done. <br /><br />I really enjoyed this collection as a whole. </span>
  <a data-text-id="1826994724393613135" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<div id="review_2157186140" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2157186140" />
    <a title="Selene Matheson " class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/22492662-selene-matheson"><img alt="Selene Matheson " src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1438583737p2/22492662.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2157186140?book_show_action=true">Dec 09, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Selene Matheson " class="user" itemprop="url" name="Selene Matheson " href="/user/show/22492662-selene-matheson">Selene Matheson </a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2157186140" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer9421867285589397645">3.5 Stars<br /><br />This book contains several feminist short stories. While I see the point to these stories the language is quite foul and I’m not enjoying that part of these stories. <br /><br />The Husbands Stitch - 4 Stars <br />This is a short story about how men feel they have a right to women’s bodies. <br /><br />Inventory - 3 Stars <br />This short story is about a woman’s sexual encounters during her life that is based on a post apocalyptic setting. <br /><br />Mothers - 2.5 Stars<br />This was an abstract story about a woman and how she came to ra</span>
  <span id="freeText9421867285589397645" style="display:none">3.5 Stars<br /><br />This book contains several feminist short stories. While I see the point to these stories the language is quite foul and I’m not enjoying that part of these stories. <br /><br />The Husbands Stitch - 4 Stars <br />This is a short story about how men feel they have a right to women’s bodies. <br /><br />Inventory - 3 Stars <br />This short story is about a woman’s sexual encounters during her life that is based on a post apocalyptic setting. <br /><br />Mothers - 2.5 Stars<br />This was an abstract story about a woman and how she came to raise a child that wasn’t “hers”. <br /><br />Especially Heinous - 4 Stars <br />This is a short collection of 272 episodes of Law and Order: SVU with supernatural elements. My mom always watches this show when I was growing up. I’ve seen a lot of the episodes and that’s why I think I liked this short story so much. <br /><br />Real Women Have Bodies - 3.5 Stars <br />This short story is based on a world where women fade. <br /><br />Eight Bites - 4 Stars <br />This short story is about a woman’s relationship with her body and food. <br /><br />The Resident - 2.5 Stars<br />This short story is about an artist who is residing in the mountains. <br /><br />Difficult at Parties - 4 Stars</span>
  <a data-text-id="9421867285589397645" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2210865526" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2210865526" />
    <a title="Paula Bardell-Hedley" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/53441266-paula-bardell-hedley"><img alt="Paula Bardell-Hedley" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1500050221p2/53441266.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2210865526?book_show_action=true">Dec 11, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Paula Bardell-Hedley" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Paula Bardell-Hedley" href="/user/show/53441266-paula-bardell-hedley">Paula Bardell-Hedley</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>

          <span class="greyText">&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;</span>
          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781781259528" href="/book/show/36934018-her-body-and-other-parties">review of another edition</a>


          <div>
    <span class="greyText">Recommended to Paula by: </span>
      NetGalley
  </div>



          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/53441266-paula-bardell-hedley?shelf=netgalley">netgalley</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/53441266-paula-bardell-hedley?shelf=lgbtq-fiction">lgbtq-fiction</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/53441266-paula-bardell-hedley?shelf=short-stories">short-stories</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/53441266-paula-bardell-hedley?shelf=feminist">feminist</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2210865526" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer2258861758827481028"><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/6860265.Carmen_Maria_Machado" title="Carmen Maria Machado" rel="nofollow">Carmen Maria Machado's</a> debut short story collection, <i><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/36934018.Her_Body_and_Other_Parties" title="Her Body and Other Parties by Carmen Maria Machado" rel="nofollow">Her Body and Other Parties</a>,</i> has marked her out as an effervescent talent in fermentation.<br /><br />Her gorgeously lubricious, fantastically deranged, genre-twisting stories explore women's bodies and the physical violence all too frequently visited upon them. Her narratives are strewn with surreal situations masquerading as humdrum lives, and many of her characters are propelled into states of half lunacy by their circumstances.<br /><br />Machado's feminal leitmot</span>
  <span id="freeText2258861758827481028" style="display:none"><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/6860265.Carmen_Maria_Machado" title="Carmen Maria Machado" rel="nofollow">Carmen Maria Machado's</a> debut short story collection, <i><a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/36934018.Her_Body_and_Other_Parties" title="Her Body and Other Parties by Carmen Maria Machado" rel="nofollow">Her Body and Other Parties</a>,</i> has marked her out as an effervescent talent in fermentation.<br /><br />Her gorgeously lubricious, fantastically deranged, genre-twisting stories explore women's bodies and the physical violence all too frequently visited upon them. Her narratives are strewn with surreal situations masquerading as humdrum lives, and many of her characters are propelled into states of half lunacy by their circumstances.<br /><br />Machado's feminal leitmotifs progress from tales of bariatric surgery and outbreaks of a fading disease to a woman's terrifying struggle to keep her sanity in the wake of a brutal attack. Nothing in these clever little fables is ever quite as it seems – and there is invariably a sinister something lurking just beyond our range of vision. <br /><br />Her language is pleasingly inventive throughout. In <i>The Resident</i>, her protagonist describes a woman's dress as a “shapeless frock whose fractal pattern spiralled dozens of holes into her torso and created in me immediate anxiety.”<br /><br />Machado's style won't appeal to everyone – especially those who insist upon neat endings to their short fiction. Nevertheless, I feel sure there will be plenty of readers delighted by such virtuoso storytelling. <br /><br />I look forward to the publication of <i>House in Indiana</i>, Machado's forthcoming memoir, due for release in 2019. (3.5 stars)<br /><br /><b>Many thanks to <a href="https://www.graywolfpress.org/" rel="nofollow"> Graywolf Press</a> for supplying an advance review copy of this title.</b></span>
  <a data-text-id="2258861758827481028" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

    <div class="updateActionLinks">

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_2214823138" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2214823138" />
    <a title="Ace" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/23405868-ace"><img alt="Ace" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1451195286p2/23405868.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2214823138?book_show_action=true">Jan 27, 2018</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Ace" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Ace" href="/user/show/23405868-ace">Ace</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/23405868-ace?shelf=tob2018-longlist">tob2018-longlist</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/23405868-ace?shelf=short-stories">short-stories</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2214823138" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer5912887744631226505">Reading these stories confirmed for me that I don't like horror stories and I like them even less when they are short stories. I was the kid around the campfire fire pleading with everyone to stop telling scary stories and couldn't we all just sing kum ba ya?<br /><br />I like back stories, a little explanation and solid endings and some of the things that make books click for me I couldn't find in this collection. Also, I must admit that there is some beautiful prose here and I was drawn to this writing an</span>
  <span id="freeText5912887744631226505" style="display:none">Reading these stories confirmed for me that I don't like horror stories and I like them even less when they are short stories. I was the kid around the campfire fire pleading with everyone to stop telling scary stories and couldn't we all just sing kum ba ya?<br /><br />I like back stories, a little explanation and solid endings and some of the things that make books click for me I couldn't find in this collection. Also, I must admit that there is some beautiful prose here and I was drawn to this writing and she can certainly create atmosphere which you can almost reach out and touch.</span>
  <a data-text-id="5912887744631226505" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

    <div class="section">


<div id="review_1967297329" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1967297329" />
    <a title="Jaclyn Crupi" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/13323030-jaclyn-crupi"><img alt="Jaclyn Crupi" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1423174778p2/13323030.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1967297329?book_show_action=true">Oct 06, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Jaclyn Crupi" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Jaclyn Crupi" href="/user/show/13323030-jaclyn-crupi">Jaclyn Crupi</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1967297329" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer5808608182165653319">These stories are 🔥🔥🔥. Jesmyn Ward might be in trouble after all... Machado plays with genre until all that remains are singular stories about women's lives and the violence visited upon their bodies. These stories are game changers. You need to read this - I can't quite believe what I just read. Also, that title! </span>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <div id="aboutAuthor" class=" clearFloats bigBox"><div class="h2Container gradientHeaderContainer"><h2 class="brownBackground"><a href="/author/show/6860265.Carmen_Maria_Machado">About Carmen Maria Machado</a></h2></div><div class="bigBoxBody"><div class="bigBoxContent containerWithHeaderContent">
          <div class='bookAuthorProfile'>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__topContainer'>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__photoContainer'>
<a href="/author/show/6860265.Carmen_Maria_Machado"><div class='bookAuthorProfile__photo' style='background-image: url(https://images.gr-assets.com/authors/1461618720p3/6860265.jpg);'></div>
</a></div>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__widgetContainer'>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__name'>
<a href="/author/show/6860265.Carmen_Maria_Machado">Carmen Maria Machado
</a></div>
<div class='goodreadsAuthorBadge'></div>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__followerCount'>
929
followers
</div>

</div>
</div>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__about'>

<span id="freeTextContainer11774817831954670225">Carmen Maria Machado's debut short story collection, Her Body and Other Parties, was a finalist for the National Book Award, the Kirkus Prize, LA Times Book Prize Art Seidenbaum Award for First Fiction, the Dylan Thomas Prize, and the PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize for Debut Fiction, and the winner of the Bard Fiction Prize, the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize, and the Crawford Awar</span>
  <span id="freeText11774817831954670225" style="display:none">Carmen Maria Machado's debut short story collection, Her Body and Other Parties, was a finalist for the National Book Award, the Kirkus Prize, LA Times Book Prize Art Seidenbaum Award for First Fiction, the Dylan Thomas Prize, and the PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize for Debut Fiction, and the winner of the Bard Fiction Prize, the National Book Critics Circle's John Leonard Prize, and the Crawford Award. In 2018, the New York Times listed Her Body and Other Parties as a member of "The New Vanguard," one of "15 remarkable books by women that are shaping the way we read and write fiction in the 21st century."<br /><br />Her essays, fiction, and criticism have appeared in the New Yorker, the New York Times, Granta, Tin House, McSweeney's Quarterly Concern, The Believer, Guernica, Best American Science Fiction &amp; Fantasy, and elsewhere. She holds an MFA from the Iowa Writers’ Workshop and has been awarded fellowships and residencies from the Michener-Copernicus Foundation, the Elizabeth George Foundation, the CINTAS Foundation, Yaddo, Hedgebrook, and the Millay Colony for the Arts. She is the Writer in Residence at the University of Pennsylvania and lives in Philadelphia with her wife.</span>
  <a data-text-id="11774817831954670225" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

</div>
</div>

<div class="clear"></div></div></div><div class="bigBoxBottom"></div></div>

      <div class=" clearFloats bigBox"><div class="h2Container gradientHeaderContainer"><h2 class="brownBackground"><a href="/trivia/work/54116423-her-body-and-other-parties">Trivia About Her Body and Othe...</a></h2></div><div class="bigBoxBody"><div class="bigBoxContent containerWithHeaderContent">
        <div class="mediumText">No trivia or quizzes yet. <a href="/trivia/work/54116423-her-body-and-other-parties">Add some now &raquo;</a></div>

      <div class=" clearFloats bigBox"><div class="h2Container gradientHeaderContainer"><h2 class="brownBackground"><a href="/work/quotes/54116423-her-body-and-other-parties">Quotes from Her Body and Othe...</a></h2></div><div class="bigBoxBody"><div class="bigBoxContent containerWithHeaderContent">
          <div class="stacked" tyle="padding-bottom:15px">
            <span class="readable">&ldquo;Many people live and die without ever confronting themselves in the darkness.&rdquo;</span>
            <nobr>
              &mdash;
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/quotes/8814610-many-people-live-and-die-without-ever-confronting-themselves-in">26 likes</a>
            </nobr>
            <div class="clear"></div>
          </div>
          <div class="stacked" tyle="padding-bottom:15px">
            <span class="readable">&ldquo;I took a step toward her. "It is my right to reside in my own mind. <i>It is my right</i>," I said. "It is my right to be unsociable and it is my right to be unpleasant to be around. Do you ever listen to yourself? This is crazy, that is crazy, everything is crazy to you. By whose measure? Well, it is my right to be crazy, as you love to say so much. I have no shame. I have felt many things in my life, but shame is not among them." The volume of my voice caused me to stand on my tiptoes. I could not remember yelling like this, ever. "You may think that I have an obligation to you but I assure you that us being thrown together in this arbitrary arrangement does not cohesion make. I have never had less of an obligation to anyone in my life, you aggressively ordinary woman.&rdquo;</span>
            <nobr>
              &mdash;
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/quotes/8971389-i-took-a-step-toward-her-it-is-my-right">20 likes</a>
            </nobr>
            <div class="clear"></div>
          </div>
        <a class="actionLink" style="float: right" href="/work/quotes/54116423-her-body-and-other-parties">More quotes&hellip;</a>
<div class="clear"></div></div></div><div class="bigBoxBottom"></div></div>

background-color: #215625; width: 0%;\" title=\"0 ratings\" data-remote=\"true\">&nbsp;<\/div>\n        <\/td>\n        <td width=\"90\">\n          0% (0)\n        <\/td>\n      <\/tr>\n\n<\/table>\n\n\n    <span class=\"value\">98<\/span>% of people liked it\n\n  <table>\n    <tr>\n      <td><strong>All editions:<\/strong><\/td>\n      <td>\n        <span class=\"value\">4.36<\/span> average rating,\n        <span class=\"value\">94<\/span> ratings,\n        <span class=\"value\">21<\/span> reviews,\n        added by <span class=\"value\">1330<\/span> people,\n        <span class=\"value\">1157<\/span> to-reads\n      <\/td>\n    <\/tr>\n\n      <tr>\n        <td><strong>This edition:<\/strong><\/td>\n        <td>\n          <span class=\"value\">4.36<\/span> average rating,\n          <span class=\"value\">94<\/span> ratings,\n          <span class=\"value\">21<\/span> reviews,\n          added by <span class=\"value\">1330<\/span> people\n        <\/td>\n      <\/tr>\n  <\/table>\n<\/div>\n\n", { style: 'goodreads', stem: 'topMiddle', hook: { tip: 'topMiddle', target: 'bottomMiddle' }, offset: { x: 5, y: 5 }, hideOn: 'click', showOn: 'click', closeButton: true, title: 'Rating details' });
      $('rating_details').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });
      $('rating_details').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

//]]>
</script><span class="greyText">&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;</span>

<span id="freeTextContainer10949730295131626204">Brand new from Topside Press, twenty-five transgender writers imagine different worlds in Meanwhile, Elsewhere: Science Fiction &amp; Fantasy from Transgender Writers.<br /><br />The #1 post-reality generation device approved for home use! This manual will prepare you to travel from multiverse to multiverse. No experience is required. Choose from twenty-five preset post-realities! Rej</span>

This manual will prepare you to travel from multiverse to multiverse. No experience is required. Choose from twenty-five preset post-realities! Rejoice at obstacles unquestionably bested and conflicts efficiently resolved. Bring denouement to your drama with THE FOOLPROOF AUGMENTATION DEVICE FOR OUR CONTEMPORARY UTOPIA.</span>

    <a class="uitext" id="span_class_gr-hyperlink_sort_span_default_tip_901" style="cursor: pointer; " href="#" onclick="return false"><span class="gr-hyperlink">Sort</span>: Default</a><script>
//<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('span_class_gr-hyperlink_sort_span_default_tip_901'), "\n        <span class=\"reviewControls__sortOrders\">\n          <span class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"><a class=\"actionLinkLite greyText loadingLink\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-keep-on-success=\"true\" data-remote=\"true\" href=\"/book/reviews/34750876-meanwhile-elsewhere?sort=default\">Default<\/a><span class=\"loadingAnimation\"><\/span><span class=\"loadingError\"><\/span><\/span>\n\n          <span class=\"greyText\">&nbsp;|&nbsp;<\/span>\n          <span class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"><a class=\"actionLinkLite  loadingLink\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-keep-on-success=\"true\" data-remote=\"true\" href=\"/book/reviews/34750876-meanwhile-elsewhere?sort=newest\">Newest<\/a><span class=\"loadingAnimation\"><\/span><span class=\"loadingError\"><\/span><\/span>\n          <span class=\"greyText\">&nbsp;|&nbsp;<\/span>\n          <span class=\"loadingLinkSpan\"><a class=\"actionLinkLite  loadingLink\" rel=\"nofollow\" data-keep-on-success=\"true\" data-remote=\"true\" href=\"/book/reviews/34750876-meanwhile-elsewhere?sort=oldest\">Oldest<\/a><span class=\"loadingAnimation\"><\/span><span class=\"loadingError\"><\/span><\/span>\n        <\/span>\n", { style: 'goodreads', stem: 'topLeft', hook: { tip: 'topLeft', target: 'bottomMiddle' }, offset: { x: 5, y: 5 }, hideOn: false, showOn: 'mouseover', closeButton: false, hideAfter: 1, hideOthers: true });
      $('span_class_gr-hyperlink_sort_span_default_tip_901').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });
      $('span_class_gr-hyperlink_sort_span_default_tip_901').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

</script>    </div>

    <div class="reviewControls--right">
    <span class="greyText">|</span>
    </div>

    <div class="reviewControls--right">
    <a class="uitext" id="span_class_gr-hyperlink_filter_span_tip_1" style="cursor: pointer; " href="#" onclick="return false"><span class="gr-hyperlink">Filter</span></a><script>

    <div class="section firstReview">


<div id="review_1968840638" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1968840638" />
    <a title="CaseyTheCanadianLesbrarian" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian"><img alt="CaseyTheCanadianLesbrarian" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1483644713p2/10463035.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1968840638?book_show_action=true">Nov 02, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="CaseyTheCanadianLesbrarian" class="user" itemprop="url" name="CaseyTheCanadianLesbrarian" href="/user/show/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian">CaseyTheCanadianLesbrarian</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=anthology">anthology</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=american">american</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=canadian">canadian</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=own">own</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=trans">trans</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=trans-fem">trans-fem</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=trans-masc">trans-masc</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=genderqueer">genderqueer</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=queer">queer</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10463035-caseythecanadianlesbrarian?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1968840638" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer8463769282483540889">Oh my God this is an amazing anthology with a huge variety of incredibly inventive, hilarious, and moving science fiction and fantasy stories by trans authors. I was totally blown away by how great the stories were. There were honestly only a few that I didn't love. It's just an astoundingly good collection. Full review <a href="https://caseythecanadianlesbrarian.com/2017/11/15/what-else-can-i-say-except-i-loved-it-a-review-of-meanwhile-elsewhere-science-fiction-and-fantasy-from-transgender-writers/" rel="nofollow">here</a>!</span>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">


<tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1968840638">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1968840638'><a id="like_count_review_1968840638" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1968840638?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">21 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F34750876-meanwhile-elsewhere">Like</a></span>

  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_1997212318" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1997212318" />
    <a title="Sally" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4061109-sally"><img alt="Sally" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1525101076p2/4061109.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1997212318?book_show_action=true">Sep 07, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Sally" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Sally" href="/user/show/4061109-sally">Sally</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4061109-sally?shelf=transgender">transgender</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4061109-sally?shelf=body-swap">body-swap</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4061109-sally?shelf=transsexual">transsexual</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4061109-sally?shelf=canadian">canadian</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1997212318" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer13761523253067401342">Meanwhile, Elsewhere: Science Fiction and Fantasy from Transgender Writers is, in a word, brilliant. You want other words? Okay, how about fantastic, original, engaging, wondrous, amusing, exciting, arousing, and intellectually stimulating. Fair enough, that last one was two words, but it needed to be said.<br /><br />Multi-author anthologies are always a hit-or-miss proposition, even when built around a theme, but Cat Fitzpatrick &amp; Casey Plett have done an astounding job here. Sure, there were a few st</span>
  <span id="freeText13761523253067401342" style="display:none">Meanwhile, Elsewhere: Science Fiction and Fantasy from Transgender Writers is, in a word, brilliant. You want other words? Okay, how about fantastic, original, engaging, wondrous, amusing, exciting, arousing, and intellectually stimulating. Fair enough, that last one was two words, but it needed to be said.<br /><br />Multi-author anthologies are always a hit-or-miss proposition, even when built around a theme, but Cat Fitzpatrick &amp; Casey Plett have done an astounding job here. Sure, there were a few stories that did not really resonate with me, but there were so many that had me committing the cardinal sins of dog-earing pages and highlighting passages that I can hardly complain.<br /><br />Rather than run through the whole collection, I would like to do something different, and count down my fave fives in the collection . . . only, there is no way I can pick just five, so I guess we will have to settle for the more clichéd top ten.<br /><br />10. Rent, Don't Sell by Calvin Gimplevich - This one starts out with the old staple of body-swapping, but puts some interesting twists on it. There is the typical joyriding by the rich, a creative means of personal training, and what seems to be a brilliant solution to gender dysphoria . . . but with a final emotional twist that I adored.<br /><br />9. What Cheer by RJ Edwards - A weird bit of sci-fi, this one puts a more thoughtful, heartfelt spin on the idea of alien body snatchers. What would you do, if a perfect clone of yourself hatched before your eyes, and only had a few short days to experience humanity?<br /><br />8. Control by Rachel K. Zall - On the surface, this is simply the story of an illicit affair between transgender lovers from different sides of the tracks, but the Orwellian influences give it a perfect edge that carries over into their frantic eroticism. It also had some of my favorite images and descriptions, including this gem:<br /><br /><i>Specks sparkled in the moonlight; they could have been tiny diamonds of miniature polished skulls. She fell through the glittering cloud and landed on top of him, grabbing his hair and smashing her lips into his. His little cock was hard between his thighs; her clit was tenting her skirt.</i><br /><br />7. Gamers by Imogen Binnie - This one had a definite nostalgic element for me, and one that really just tickled my fancy. I have never really been a gamer, but I do have an old-school passion for Zelda, so Samara's story . . . well, it just made me smile.<br /><br />6. Thieves and Lovers by Emma Addams - This is a story about role playing, costumes, identities, secrets, and more, but with a sci-fi twist. Imagine if you will a world of wearable holograms, one where themed genre bars exist. There is a lovely story here of attraction and seduction, contrasting dreams with reality, and it all just clicks.<br /><br />5. The Gift by Ryka Aoki - This is probably the least progressive story in terms of technology, but the most progressive in terms of attitudes. It was a sweet, easy-going, uplifting story of coming out as transgender and being immediately loved and accepted. My heart still swells over this one.<br /><br />4. Delicate Bodies by Bridget Liang - When being transgender is so often treated by like a disease, and when so much of society treats you as a monstrous freak, maybe becoming a sentient flesh-eating zombie isn't such a bad thing. This was a fantastic story, equal parts dark and quirky, with a truly brilliant final paragraph.<br /><br />3. Themyscira by Colette Arrand - I think a big part of the appeal here was in how it subverted my expectations. Here we have an island of voluntary exiles, with one young woman feeling out of place due to being the only one with a penis - at least, until another transgender girl washes up on shore. This one pairs well with Delicate Bodies, looking at gender as a disease, and exploring how it infects those around us.<br /><br />2. Matchmaker by Dane Figueroa Edidi - In terms of sheer story, this is far-and-away my favorite in the collection. This could have been a blockbuster sized epic novel, and I still would have wanted more. A magic-fueled urban fantasy, full of colorful characters, plot twists, and betrayals, it hinges on the simple idea that a transwoman could be close enough to the Goddess to be a witch, but it is so much more than that.<br /><br />1. Satan, Are You There? It's Me, Laura by Aisling Fae - No other story in the collection amused me, delighted me, and entertained me quite like this. This is a gloriously blasphemous story about a girl who tried to summon Satan and got God in disguise, and who then goes on to play matchmaker for the star-crossed lovers. It is full of so many little moments, so many clever deconstructions of religion, but it all boils down to this:<br /><br /><i>"What do you think people would think, if they knew their terrible Devil was some tranny and their God a fag?"</i><br /><br />Perhaps the best collection of transgender fiction I have ever had the pleasure of reading, Meanwhile, Elsewhere: Science Fiction and Fantasy from Transgender Writers has only one small flaw, and that is the absence of author biographies. Maybe they are just missing from the ARCs, and will show up in the finished product but, damn it, I want to know more about my sisters!<br /><br />As reviewed by Sally at <a href="http://bibrary.blogspot.ca/2017/09/meanwhile-elsewhere-edited-by-cat.html" rel="nofollow">Bending the Bookshelf</a></span>
  <a data-text-id="13761523253067401342" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1990175384?book_show_action=true">Feb 15, 2018</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">

          added it

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1990175384'><a id="like_count_review_1990175384" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1990175384?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">4 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F34750876-meanwhile-elsewhere">Like</a></span>

<div id="review_1978435052" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1978435052" />
    <a title="B.P. Gregory" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/16315920-b-p-gregory"><img alt="B.P. Gregory" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1527332195p2/16315920.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1978435052?book_show_action=true">May 27, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="B.P. Gregory" class="user" itemprop="url" name="B.P. Gregory" href="/user/show/16315920-b-p-gregory">B.P. Gregory</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1978435052" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer7506975473474866683">What are we reading?: Meanwhile, Elsewhere, Science Fiction and Fantasy from Transgender Writers, edited by Cat Fitzpatrick and Casey Plett.<br /><br />Give me the short version: Tired of the same old from your science fiction? Looking for the next read that’ll remind you how it feels to be alive?<br /><br /><br />Back in the good old university days one of the authors published in Meanwhile, Elsewhere used to boggle my mind and pith my nightmares with her tales, so I was lucky enough to nab an advance copy in exchange for a</span>
  <span id="freeText7506975473474866683" style="display:none">What are we reading?: Meanwhile, Elsewhere, Science Fiction and Fantasy from Transgender Writers, edited by Cat Fitzpatrick and Casey Plett.<br /><br />Give me the short version: Tired of the same old from your science fiction? Looking for the next read that’ll remind you how it feels to be alive?<br /><br /><br />Back in the good old university days one of the authors published in Meanwhile, Elsewhere used to boggle my mind and pith my nightmares with her tales, so I was lucky enough to nab an advance copy in exchange for an honest review.<br /><br />Like all anthologies there were a couple of stories that brought neither highs nor lows and a bunch I absolutely loved, and that had me scrambling to buy more more more from their authors. With Meanwhile, Elsewhere being such a wonderfully chunky publication (twenty-five tales) there’s something for everybody.<br /><br />A few I really enjoyed included the intriguing possibilities and cruel legal tangles of Calvin Gimpelevich’s body-swapping Rent, Don’t Sell; the brutal compassion and street justice of Paige Bryony’s voyeuristic Control Shift Down; and the quiet lonely worry of space travel that Sadie Avery painted in Using a Treadmill You Can Run Until Exhaustion Without Moving.<br /><br />Collette Arrand’s dreamy stylised island quarantine of Themyscira is a good one to have a pause and a quiet think after; the crazy high-octane trash-cyberpunk of Sybil Lamb’s Cybervania was a personal, personal favourite; and of course the frail beauty and sweet mournful introspection of Tristan Alice Nieto’s lovely resurrectionist piece Imago.<br /><br /><br />My favourite bit: “Far from the fairytale meeting of love across distant realms, it was usually a confused and perverse confrontation as people tried in vain to locate a tiny fragment of the person they once knew within the talking pile of human remains that wore their lover’s skin.” – Imago, Tristan Alice Nieto.<br /></span>
  <a data-text-id="7506975473474866683" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1978435052'><a id="like_count_review_1978435052" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1978435052?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">4 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F34750876-meanwhile-elsewhere">Like</a></span>
