    <div class="elementListBrownSeparator"></div>



  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_1738299384" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1738299384" />
    <a title="Polenth Blake" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4384861-polenth-blake"><img alt="Polenth Blake" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442513763p2/4384861.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1738299384?book_show_action=true">Sep 12, 2016</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Polenth Blake" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Polenth Blake" href="/user/show/4384861-polenth-blake">Polenth Blake</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>

          <span class="greyText">&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;</span>
          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780993997075" href="/book/show/31560094-love-beyond-body-space-and-time">review of another edition</a>





          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4384861-polenth-blake?shelf=review-copy">review-copy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4384861-polenth-blake?shelf=short-fiction">short-fiction</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4384861-polenth-blake?shelf=science-fiction">science-fiction</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/4384861-polenth-blake?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1738299384" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer4495785008217759932">This anthology focuses on Native American two-spirit and QUILTBAG stories. All authors are Native, but not all of them are QUILTBAG. It opens with an introduction from the editor, followed by two pieces that introduce the theme and a little bit about the history of two-spirit people. There are eight stories and one poem, so it's a relatively short anthology.<br /><br />There are a number of reoccurring themes. Nations sending out colonists into space is one, and is handled differently in each story that rai</span>
  <span id="freeText4495785008217759932" style="display:none">This anthology focuses on Native American two-spirit and QUILTBAG stories. All authors are Native, but not all of them are QUILTBAG. It opens with an introduction from the editor, followed by two pieces that introduce the theme and a little bit about the history of two-spirit people. There are eight stories and one poem, so it's a relatively short anthology.<br /><br />There are a number of reoccurring themes. Nations sending out colonists into space is one, and is handled differently in each story that raises it. Another is what makes someone a member of a tribe. "Valediction at the Star View Motel " (Nathan Adler) has a white girl who was adopted as a child, and "Imposter Syndrome" (Mari Kurisato) is about a non-human trying to get on a colony ship. Both stories share a similar theme, of the tribe viewing a person as a member for being part of the community, and the outside not wanting to acknowledge that. I also liked that "Imposter Syndrome" has an asexual aromantic character. It's clear this is not because she's non-human, as another non-human wants a relationship.<br /><br />A number of the stories are romances. "Né łe!" (Darcie Little Badger) was my favourite of these, as it was about slowly getting to know someone, rather than love at first sight. The concept of transporting pet dogs for wealthy colonists was also fun. A more serious note to the story is about sovereignty, and the contrast between tribes when it comes to being able to maintain it. The Navajo Nation has its own space colony. Whereas the protagonist is Lipan Apache, and her family is forced to leave their farm, with no new home in the stars.<br /><br />I liked the focus on a parent and child relationship in "Legends Are Made, Not Born" (Cherie Dimaline). Auntie Dave is raising the protagonist, which includes training in two-spirit community responsibilities. It shows ties between two-spirit people outside of sexual relationships, which really shouldn't be as rare as it is in stories.<br /><br />Though there are a lot of positive things, I didn't like "Aliens" (Richard Van Camp). Unfortunately, this was the first story, so wasn't a good start to the anthology for me. I did like how it was told as people verbally tell stories, but I had some concerns when it was suggested that Jimmy being a gentle person who wasn't having relationships would mean his life was forgettable. As though it's not a proper life without sexual relationships. And then once he does have a relationship, the shift is to making fun of his genitals. It's implied he's intersex, though even if that wasn't the specific identity intended, he's still going to be in one of the groups that frequently gets reduced to being a set of genitals. Those jokes do not feel like jokes to the person constantly on the receiving end of them. Had the story been told from Jimmy's perspective, and not treated like it was funny, I might have reacted differently. But it was from the perspective of the people doing the laughing. It was presented as a warm and positive thing. Fortunately, it's the only story in the anthology that isn't from the perspective of a two-spirit person.<br /><br />There is some representation across the QUILTBAG, though it's stronger on LGT than the rest. Lesbians are particularly well represented. Others are less so. I do wish the one possible intersex character had not been handled that way. The binary-gendered language of some of the stories also stood out. This is talking about both genders, rather than all genders. It's having male roles and female roles, but no room for other roles. Which is an odd choice when the focus is on two-spirit people.<br /><br />Note that some stories contain descriptions of rape and assault (particularly "Imposter Syndrome"). The term halfbreed is used in a few stories. It's in a reclaiming context, rather than being used as an insult, but still something mixed race people might want to know is coming in advance.<br /><br />It's generally a strong anthology, with a range of approaches to speculative fiction. There are stories where the speculative elements are very light, space adventures, and fantasy. It has cultural representations that do not fall into stereotypes and othering. The QUILTBAG content was mostly good, but there were areas where it was spotty.<br /><br />[A copy of this book was received from the publisher for review purposes]<br /><br />Review from: <a href="http://blog.polenthblake.com/2016/09/love-beyond-body-space-time/" rel="nofollow">http://blog.polenthblake.com/2016/09/love-beyond-body-space-time/</a></span>
  <a data-text-id="4495785008217759932" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<span id="freeTextContainer780531898433984255">Hope Nicholson is the owner of Winnipeg-based publishing Bedside Press. She's an ardent comics fan passionate about bringing new stories to light, and author of the book "The Spectacular Sisterhood of Superwomen" which shines light on characters forgotten by comics history.</span>

      $('rating_details').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });
      $('rating_details').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

<div id="descriptionContainer">

      <div id="description" class="readable stacked" style="right:0">

<span id="freeTextContainer7326279188465586017">The complete first year of GlitterShip Magazine.<br /><br />In these pages you'll find characters who transcend space and time: resistance fighters, superheroes, magicians, artists, technicians, robots, lovers, faeries, thieves, sailors—and even one righteously pissed-off Cinderella.<br /><br />Collecting the more than 30 stories that have previously appeared in GlitterShip, this anthology shows</span>
  <span id="freeText7326279188465586017" style="display:none">The complete first year of GlitterShip Magazine.<br /><br />In these pages you'll find characters who transcend space and time: resistance fighters, superheroes, magicians, artists, technicians, robots, lovers, faeries, thieves, sailors—and even one righteously pissed-off Cinderella.<br /><br />Collecting the more than 30 stories that have previously appeared in GlitterShip, this anthology shows that the worlds of LGBTQ science fiction and fantasy are vast and magical. A mix of established, award-winning authors and new writers you've been waiting to meet, GlitterShip brings you a variety of voices to read and enjoy.</span>
  <a data-text-id="7326279188465586017" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

      </div>
</div>

  <div id=asyncBuyButtonContainer class="uitext buttons buyableFeature u-marginTopXSmall u-paddingBottomXSmall u-bottomGrayBorder" data-book-id=35916896 >

    <div class="u-positionRelative">
      <h2 class='buyButtonContainer__title u-inlineBlock'%>Get A Copy</h2>

    </div>

        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });
      $('span_class_gr-hyperlink_filter_span_tip_302').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

      <div id="aboutAuthor" class=" clearFloats bigBox"><div class="h2Container gradientHeaderContainer"><h2 class="brownBackground"><a href="/author/show/4133755.Keffy_R_M_Kehrli">About Keffy R.M. Kehrli</a></h2></div><div class="bigBoxBody"><div class="bigBoxContent containerWithHeaderContent">
          <div class='bookAuthorProfile'>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__topContainer'>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__photoContainer'>
<a href="/author/show/4133755.Keffy_R_M_Kehrli"><div class='bookAuthorProfile__photo' style='background-image: url(https://images.gr-assets.com/authors/1425413428p3/4133755.jpg);'></div>
</a></div>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__widgetContainer'>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__name'>
<a href="/author/show/4133755.Keffy_R_M_Kehrli">Keffy R.M. Kehrli
</a></div>
<div class='goodreadsAuthorBadge'></div>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__followerCount'>
19
followers
</div>

</div>
</div>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__about'>

<span id="freeTextContainer959609092126124436">Keffy is a speculative fiction writer currently living on Long Island, where he is working toward a PhD in Genetics.<br /><br />His short fiction has been published in Apex, Fantasy Magazine, Lightspeed, and Uncanny, among other places.<br /><br />He is currently the editor and publisher of GlitterShip magazine.</span>

</div>
</div>

        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });
      $('rating_details').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

<div id="descriptionContainer">

      <div id="description" class="readable stacked" style="right:0">

<span id="freeTextContainer9798352752620960806">You can't belong to the Thieves' Guild if you can't break into the Thieves' Guild. When Terizan dropped out of the secret passage, past the net, and into the Inner Sanctum, she was astonished to discover that no one else had ever made it that far. Unfortunately, neither Terizan nor the Guild are thrilled about the sudden perception that she's the best thief in Oreen – the</span>
  <span id="freeText9798352752620960806" style="display:none">You can't belong to the Thieves' Guild if you can't break into the Thieves' Guild. When Terizan dropped out of the secret passage, past the net, and into the Inner Sanctum, she was astonished to discover that no one else had ever made it that far. Unfortunately, neither Terizan nor the Guild are thrilled about the sudden perception that she's the best thief in Oreen – the title comes with expectations and the Guild only ever expects the worst. In these five tales, mercenary captains, murderous royal families, ghosts, gods, and wizards prove that while it may not always be lonely at the top, it's definitely annoying. Good thing half a dozen gods owe Terizan a favour.<br /><p>
  <br /></p> Swan's Braid<br />  In Mysterious Ways<br />  The Lions of Al'Kalamir<br />  Sometimes, Just Because<br />  The Things Everyone Knows<br /><p>All previously collected (non-e-book) in Stealing Magic</p> </span>
  <a data-text-id="9798352752620960806" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

      </div>
</div>

    </div>

      });

//]]>
</script>  </div>

<div id="bookReviews">





  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section firstReview">


<div id="review_1553660172" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1553660172" />
    <a title="Shira Glassman" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/22722961-shira-glassman"><img alt="Shira Glassman" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442944087p2/22722961.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1553660172?book_show_action=true">Oct 03, 2016</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Shira Glassman" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Shira Glassman" href="/user/show/22722961-shira-glassman">Shira Glassman</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22722961-shira-glassman?shelf=femslash">femslash</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22722961-shira-glassman?shelf=ff-sff">ff-sff</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22722961-shira-glassman?shelf=sff-speculative">sff-speculative</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1553660172" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer10648573370103972877">Fantasy literature is rife with ‘clever thief’ protagonists for the vicarious entertainment of the virtuous, like Bilbo Baggins, but most of them are not even female, let alone lesbians. Swan’s Braid and other Tales of Terizan gives us the wily but honorable Terizan, who waltzes away from the first story in her collection with the affection of a female mercenary with whom she maintains a casual romance for the remainder of the book. Most of Terizan’s adventures aren’t love stories, but “capers”–</span>
  <span id="freeText10648573370103972877" style="display:none">Fantasy literature is rife with ‘clever thief’ protagonists for the vicarious entertainment of the virtuous, like Bilbo Baggins, but most of them are not even female, let alone lesbians. Swan’s Braid and other Tales of Terizan gives us the wily but honorable Terizan, who waltzes away from the first story in her collection with the affection of a female mercenary with whom she maintains a casual romance for the remainder of the book. Most of Terizan’s adventures aren’t love stories, but “capers”–she gets assignments from the Thieves’ Guild, which she joined pretty much for their health insurance plan (“the guild takes care of its own,” and she’s worried about what would happen if she ever got more seriously hurt during one of her falls from a mark’s window. It’s that kind of book.)<br /><br />The plots themselves are pretty clever, with inflection points and twists and rising action and punch lines, reminding me of <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/1569298.Maurice_Leblanc" title="Maurice Leblanc" rel="nofollow">Maurice Leblanc</a>’s dashing gentleman burglar Arsène Lupin, only in a fantasy setting with a lesbian heroine. Whether Terizan’s adversary is a ghost, a wizard, a prince, or the cult of an upstart goddess, reading about her besting them was satisfying and not stressful at all because they’re written in that “good old fashioned fun” way, not grimdark.<br /><br />The prose is easy to follow, with the occasional evocative bit like “[…]sales pitches as wilted as the vegetables[…]” Huff’s worldbuilding is unobtrusive and “generic fantasy” enough to be pretty easy to understand, yet with enough originality that I didn’t feel like I was reading homage or parody. And I really can’t say enough good things about how relaxing it is to read a story about a woman Doing Things in a shady underworld without having to fear gendered violence. The villains in this book are mostly men, but their offensives and defenses against Terizan never include a sexual element.<br /><br />I love so much about what Terizan’s stories have and don’t have. Her best friend is a bisexual male sex worker, her adventures aren’t gendered (in other words, she gets to interact with her fictional universe pretty much the way male characters usually get to), and her three bosses at the Guild are a man, a woman, and someone who “could be either or neither” whose gender is never further discussed. These days things like this are becoming easier to find in SFF, at least if you’re like me and play Heimdahl with indie LGBT publishing, but this particular story was written in the NINETIES. So I quietly hold this up to those who go around leaving skeptical, ossified reviews on fiction with nonbinary characters.<br /><br />I would love to see these done in graphic novel form.<br /><br />(Warning for the word ‘whore’ used a few times; I think it was only said by the sex worker character but I can’t actually remember and I returned my eBook to the library already.)</span>
  <a data-text-id="10648573370103972877" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1553660172'><a id="like_count_review_1553660172" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1553660172?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">8 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F18068282-swan-s-braid-and-other-tales-of-terizan">Like</a></span>

  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_661160311" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/661160311" />
    <a title="Nikki " class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/223837-nikki"><img alt="Nikki " src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1308224598p2/223837.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/661160311?book_show_action=true">Jul 07, 2013</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Nikki " class="user" itemprop="url" name="Nikki " href="/user/show/223837-nikki">Nikki </a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/223837-nikki?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/223837-nikki?shelf=short-stories-novellas">short-stories-novellas</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/223837-nikki?shelf=queer">queer</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer661160311" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer2888559287699641051">I didn't know, in my recent spree of buying lesbian fantasy, that this counted. I know Tanya Huff has LGBT hero/ines elsewhere, but I bought Swan's Braid purely because it's Tanya Huff and I've enjoyed her other short story collections. Terizan is a fun heroine -- morally ambiguous at times, but fun, able to take care of herself <i>and</i> ask for help when she needs it. There's not much detail to the world, only what's necessary for each story, but at least it doesn't get bogged down in <i>unnecessary</i> de</span>
  <span id="freeText2888559287699641051" style="display:none">I didn't know, in my recent spree of buying lesbian fantasy, that this counted. I know Tanya Huff has LGBT hero/ines elsewhere, but I bought Swan's Braid purely because it's Tanya Huff and I've enjoyed her other short story collections. Terizan is a fun heroine -- morally ambiguous at times, but fun, able to take care of herself <i>and</i> ask for help when she needs it. There's not much detail to the world, only what's necessary for each story, but at least it doesn't get bogged down in <i>unnecessary</i> detail. <br /><br />Some of the side/recurring characters are pretty fun, too. I was kinda sad once I finished the last story: even though there's no particular arc of story development linking the pieces, I did get invested in what becomes of them all.<br /><br />Given that I only paid £1.99 for it on the Kindle store, definitely worth it.</span>
  <a data-text-id="2888559287699641051" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_661160311'><a id="like_count_review_661160311" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/661160311?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">4 likes</span></a>&nbsp;&middot;&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F18068282-swan-s-braid-and-other-tales-of-terizan">Like</a></span>

  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_710656859" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/710656859" />
    <a title="Azure Rose" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/5924002-azure-rose"><img alt="Azure Rose" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1375595094p2/5924002.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/710656859?book_show_action=true">Sep 03, 2013</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Azure Rose" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Azure Rose" href="/user/show/5924002-azure-rose">Azure Rose</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer710656859" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer1769460998133934551">While I am not generally a fan of Tanya Huff, I found this somewhat short group of stories featuring the canny and witty not to mention, charmingly intrigued with women, (or perhaps I should say one woman), Terizan the thief to be a relatively fun romp in an alternate world that is both Middle-Eastern and points all along the Silk Road inspired. Huff is able to write about a woman who is attracted to other women in such a way that it does not make the stories seem trite or biased towards any par</span>
  <span id="freeText1769460998133934551" style="display:none">While I am not generally a fan of Tanya Huff, I found this somewhat short group of stories featuring the canny and witty not to mention, charmingly intrigued with women, (or perhaps I should say one woman), Terizan the thief to be a relatively fun romp in an alternate world that is both Middle-Eastern and points all along the Silk Road inspired. Huff is able to write about a woman who is attracted to other women in such a way that it does not make the stories seem trite or biased towards any particular audience. There are some weak moments scattered throughout, perhaps these stories could have used a bit more development and detail, but they were satisfying for an evening's departure to points unknown. They make me wish I still had my copies of the Anthology series, Liavek, if that should prove helpful. </span>
  <a data-text-id="1769460998133934551" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

<span id="freeTextContainer16608208798647490166">Great collection of Tanya Huff's thief, Terizan, and how she deals with the bureaucracy of the Guild while practicing her craft. Terizan is not only the best thief, she is also practical - she joins the Guild for the insurance and retirement benefits. She has an odd moral center that makes her even more likable.   <span id="freeText16608208798647490166" style="display:none">Great collection of Tanya Huff's thief, Terizan, and how she deals with the bureaucracy of the Guild while practicing her craft. Terizan is not only the best thief, she is also practical - she joins the Guild for the insurance and retirement benefits. She has an odd moral center that makes her even more likable. Stealing is acceptable but allowing a less skilled thief to take a job that could cost him his life - not acceptable. Allowing a corporate religion to consume the powers of the independent, smaller religions - no way. Violence is never acceptable and she goes to great lengths to avoid it. </span>

<div id="review_2028291940" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2028291940" />
    <a title="Lindsay Eimert" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/68581658-lindsay-eimert"><img alt="Lindsay Eimert" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1497455186p2/68581658.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/2028291940?book_show_action=true">Jun 13, 2017</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Lindsay Eimert" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Lindsay Eimert" href="/user/show/68581658-lindsay-eimert">Lindsay Eimert</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer2028291940" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer17644228760591017078">This collection of short stories is a great deal of fun. Some of the stories are stronger than others in both concept and execution (and I personally wish we saw a bit more of the titular character), but overall, Terizan’s adventures proved consistently charming, funny, and a delight to read. I would absolutely love to see more work focused on these characters.</span>

          </span>
        </div>

<div id="review_2065505162" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/2065505162" />
    <a title="Kathryn Baron" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/24013552-kathryn-baron"><img alt="Kathryn Baron" src="https://s.gr-assets.com/assets/nophoto/user/u_50x66-632230dc9882b4352d753eedf9396530.png" /></a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Kathryn Baron" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Kathryn Baron" href="/user/show/24013552-kathryn-baron">Kathryn Baron</a>

          </span>

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_2065505162'><a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F18068282-swan-s-braid-and-other-tales-of-terizan">Like</a></span>

  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_1040539691" class="review nosyndicate" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1040539691" />
    <a title="Heather" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/5506829-heather"><img alt="Heather" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442453847p2/5506829.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1040539691?book_show_action=true">Aug 30, 2014</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Heather" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Heather" href="/user/show/5506829-heather">Heather</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1040539691" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer13030544497505544614">Swan’s Braid and Other Tales of Terizan is a collection of short stories by Tanya Huff, all featuring the thief Terizan. Terizan is a great thief, and the Tribunes of the Thieves’ Guild feel just a tad threatened by her skills and ambition–thus they continually maneuver her into difficult and dangerous assignments. Good thievery plots are hard to pull off, because the author has to be very on the ball to keep up with reader expectations of cleverness. Tanya Huff does a fantastic job of it. I lov</span>
  <span id="freeText13030544497505544614" style="display:none">Swan’s Braid and Other Tales of Terizan is a collection of short stories by Tanya Huff, all featuring the thief Terizan. Terizan is a great thief, and the Tribunes of the Thieves’ Guild feel just a tad threatened by her skills and ambition–thus they continually maneuver her into difficult and dangerous assignments. Good thievery plots are hard to pull off, because the author has to be very on the ball to keep up with reader expectations of cleverness. Tanya Huff does a fantastic job of it. I love the ways in which Terizan gets into trouble, gets out of trouble, and pulls one over on the people who try to harm or trick her. I also love the fact that she isn’t infallible, and her own ambitions and ego sometimes trip her up.<br /><br />In Swan’s Braid, Terizan falls for a beautiful mercenary captain named Swan. Swan, however, has her own reasons for finding Terizan captivating. Toss in Terizan’s first test from the Thieves’ Guild and a local leader with criminal connections, and Terizan has to think fast to keep her head above water.<br /><br />In Mysterious Ways gives us a great peek into the ins-and-outs of belief in small gods, and how those small gods can still affect their believers–and those who cross them. Terizan’s latest Guild assignment lands her in trouble with one of those gods with hilariously dangerous results.<br /><br />The Lions of Al’Kalamir is almost-sort-of a classic tomb/dungeon crawl, with plenty of traps for the unwary and enjoyable plot twists along the way. Terizan gets herself into things at Swan’s behest in order to head off a civil war, but of course someone has to complicate things by pulling one over on her.<br /><br />Sometimes, Just Because pits Terizan against a powerful wizard, which might just be her most dangerous assignment yet. Terizan’s ambition trips her up a bit in this one, but she isn’t being as foolish as she might seem.<br /><br />The Things Everyone Knows sends Terizan into the realm of crypts, tombs, and ghosts in order to head off a political conspiracy–not exactly something she wants to involve herself in, but the Guild once again has her number. This one brings her full circle back to the events of the first story and introduces another unusual small god with interesting influences.<br /><br />Thievery plots are so difficult to pull off well. They require a lot of cleverness on the thief’s part, and too often that devolves into what I call the “think like the author” problem–the only reason the thief succeeds is because they can effectively read the author’s mind. Tanya Huff avoids this beautifully. Terizan is genuinely clever on her own merits. She also is flawed without being too foolish, a balance that’s hard to maintain. My only disappointment with Swan’s Braid is that I hated running out of stories to read!<br /><br /><br />For a longer review, visit my site: <a target="_blank" href="http://www.errantdreams.com/2014/08/review-swans-braid-tanya-huff/" rel="nofollow">http://www.errantdreams.com/2014/08/r...</a></span>
  <a data-text-id="13030544497505544614" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1040539691'><a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F18068282-swan-s-braid-and-other-tales-of-terizan">Like</a></span>

    </div>

<div id="review_1857765647" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1857765647" />
    <a title="annapi" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1718859-annapi"><img alt="annapi" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1453255239p2/1718859.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/1857765647?book_show_action=true">Dec 30, 2016</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="annapi" class="user" itemprop="url" name="annapi" href="/user/show/1718859-annapi">annapi</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="really liked it"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1718859-annapi?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1718859-annapi?shelf=short-stories">short-stories</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer1857765647" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer7510219968308067397">This is a collection of five fantasy short stories all featuring the thief Terizan. I've read some of them in other collections, and they're all clever and enjoyable. Not sure if there are any more Terizan stories, or if Huff intends to write more, but I hope she does as the character is a fun one. The title story is the first one, and tells how Terizan joins the Thieves' Guild. It's said that you can't join unless you break into the Guild, and so she does - and discovers that she's the first on</span>
  <span id="freeText7510219968308067397" style="display:none">This is a collection of five fantasy short stories all featuring the thief Terizan. I've read some of them in other collections, and they're all clever and enjoyable. Not sure if there are any more Terizan stories, or if Huff intends to write more, but I hope she does as the character is a fun one. The title story is the first one, and tells how Terizan joins the Thieves' Guild. It's said that you can't join unless you break into the Guild, and so she does - and discovers that she's the first one to ever do so, earning her the reputation as the best thief in Oreen. Unfortunately she finds that the title comes with expectations, which leads to her other adventures.</span>
  <a data-text-id="7510219968308067397" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">

      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1857765647'><a rel="nofollow" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small" href="https://www.goodreads.com/user/new?remember=true&amp;return_url=%2Fbook%2Fshow%2F18068282-swan-s-braid-and-other-tales-of-terizan">Like</a></span>

  <div class="friendReviews elementListBrown" >
    <div class="section">


<div id="review_663500715" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/663500715" />
    <a title="Ann aka Iftcan" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/426768-ann-aka-iftcan"><img alt="Ann aka Iftcan" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1250000528p2/426768.jpg" /></a>

  <div class="left bodycol">
    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/663500715?book_show_action=true">Jul 09, 2013</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Ann aka Iftcan" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Ann aka Iftcan" href="/user/show/426768-ann-aka-iftcan">Ann aka Iftcan</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">
            Shelves:
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/426768-ann-aka-iftcan?shelf=a-book-a-day-challenge">a-book-a-day-challenge</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/426768-ann-aka-iftcan?shelf=anthology">anthology</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/426768-ann-aka-iftcan?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/426768-ann-aka-iftcan?shelf=humour">humour</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/426768-ann-aka-iftcan?shelf=magic">magic</a>,
              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/426768-ann-aka-iftcan?shelf=wizards">wizards</a>
          </div>
    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer663500715" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer5386216988431702385">A nice collection of the stories of Terizan, the best thief in her home City. She's the only candidate for the Thieve's Guild who ever manages to actually <i>complete</i> the trial to join. <br /><br />There is humour as well as good story telling in this collection by Huff. She also has a little bit of romance, in that she falls in love with a mercenary named Swan. Yes, the Swan who's braid is the title of this collection of stories. <br /><br /></span>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">


<tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review663500715">

<div id="review_698653000" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">
  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/698653000" />
    <a title="Stuart" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2929380-stuart"><img alt="Stuart" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442512621p2/2929380.jpg" /></a>

    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">
        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" href="/review/show/698653000?book_show_action=true">Aug 19, 2013</a>

      <span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
        <a title="Stuart" class="user" itemprop="url" name="Stuart" href="/user/show/2929380-stuart">Stuart</a>
      </span>

        rated it
        <span class=" staticStars" title="it was amazing"><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>






    </div>


        <div class="reviewText stacked">
              <span id="reviewTextContainer698653000" class="readable"
              >

<span id="freeTextContainer17676602036764774627">This is a collection of short stories featuring Tanya Huff's thief, Terizan. They're good, fun tales, with a lot of wit and cleverness, and some good takes on traditional fantasy ideas.</span>

          </span>
        </div>


      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">


<tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review698653000">

//<![CDATA[

  function submitShelfLink(unique_id, book_id, shelf_id, shelf_name, submit_form, exclusive) {
    var checkbox_id = 'shelf_name_' + unique_id + '_' + shelf_id;
    var element = document.getElementById(checkbox_id)

    var checked = element.checked
    if (checked && exclusive) {
      // can't uncheck a radio by clicking it!
      return
    }
    if(document.getElementById("savingMessage")){
      Element.show('savingMessage')
    }
    var element_id = 'shelfInDropdownName_' + unique_id + '_' + shelf_id;
    Element.update(element_id, "saving...");
    if (submit_form) {
      Element.hide('shelfDropdown_' + unique_id)
      var form = document.getElementById('addBookForm' + book_id)
      if (form) {
        form.shelf.value = shelf_name
        form.onsubmit()
      }
    }
    else {
      var action = checked ? 'remove' : ''
      element.checked = !element.checked
      new Ajax.Request('/shelf/add_to_shelf', {asynchronous:true, evalScripts:true, onSuccess:function(request){shelfSubmitted(request, book_id, checkbox_id, element_id, unique_id, shelf_name)}, parameters:'book_id=' + book_id + '&name=' + shelf_name + '&a=' + action + '&authenticity_token=' + encodeURIComponent('Adbg5T6UaUPPSRXIOv4sQJMkWJaFvXF20wdQhJvGT2zTBAD7YybJDGsh9/4ehvcBXxdn2BJ9A5pY73FxJFeS8w==')})
    }
  }

  function shelfSubmitted(request, book_id, checkbox_id, element_id, unique_id, shelf_name) {
    Element.update('shelfListfalse_' + book_id, request.responseText)
    afterShelfSave(checkbox_id, element_id, unique_id, shelf_name.escapeHTML())
  }

  function refreshGroupBox(group_id, book_id) {
    new Ajax.Updater('addGroupBooks' + book_id + '', '/group/add_book_box', {asynchronous:true, evalScripts:true, onSuccess:function(request){refreshGroupBoxComplete(request, book_id);}, parameters:'id=' + group_id + '&book_id=' + book_id + '&refresh=true' + '&authenticity_token=' + encodeURIComponent('o9ky7ysrIRgT34XBXfBRL0BEZlWOksRrwUKxCCIs8DdxC9LxdpmBV7e3Z/d5iIpujHdZGxlStodKqpD9nb0tqA==')})
  }
//]]>
</script>

      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_671799'), "\n\n  <h2><a class=\"readable bookTitle\" href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/671799.Places_to_Be_People_to_Kill?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\">Places to Be, People to Kill<\/a><\/h2>\n\n      <div>\n        by <a class=\"authorName\" href=\"/author/show/6436872.Martin_H_Greenberg?a=7&amp;origin=related_works\">Martin H. Friesner<\/a>\n      <\/div>\n\n          <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n            <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p10\"><\/span><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p10\"><\/span><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p10\"><\/span><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p6\"><\/span><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p0\"><\/span><\/span> 3.61 avg rating &mdash; 140 ratings<\/span>            &mdash; published 2010\n          <\/div>\n\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      \n<span id=\"freeTextContainer3640393110456011154\">The Follow-Up to Witch Way to the Mall and Strip Mauled from the Creator of the Chicks in Chainmail Series.  Here Come the Vampires to Put the Bite on Suburbia. Having inflicted the smug homes of suburbia with witches and werewolves. Esther Friesner<\/span>\n  <span id=\"freeText3640393110456011154\" style=\"display:none\">The Follow-Up to Witch Way to the Mall and Strip Mauled from the Creator of the Chicks in Chainmail Series.  Here Come the Vampires to Put the Bite on Suburbia. Having inflicted the smug homes of suburbia with witches and werewolves. Esther Friesner now unleashes the undead to tap a vein of blood and humor, and drain the suburbs dry of both. Vampires and the suburbs are a match made in heaven, or maybe Levittown. Remember Dracula? He didn’t run into any real problems until he took his act on the road and traveled to the BigCity. But in the suburbs, everyone is polite and respectful of their neighbors’ right to privacy. And if your neighbors happen to have kids selling gift-wrap, magazine subscriptions, cookies, or other school fundraising ploys, and little Emily or Jason happen to come peddling their wares after sundown . . .  Who says you have to stay in the city if you want good take-out meals delivered right to your door? There’s no one quite like a vampire for saying, “All of you kids get off of my lawn!” and putting some teeth  into it. The stories in these pages—by Sarah A. Hoyt, K.D. Wentworth, Dave Freer and more, including Esther Friesner herself—will convince the reader that vampires and suburbs go together like wine and cheese, gin and tonic, desperation and housewives, marriage and pre-nups.       $('bookCover_7683167').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });

      newTip['wrapper'].addClassName('prototipAllowOverflow');

        $('bookCover_7683167').observe('prototip:shown', function () {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function (e) {
            if ($('bookCover_7683167').hasClassName('ignored')) {
              e.setStyle({'display': 'none'});
              return;
            }
            e.setStyle({'overflow': 'visible'});
          });
        });
      $('bookCover_7683167').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

<script>
//<![CDATA[
      var newTip = new Tip($('bookCover_22750124'), "\n\n  <h2><a class=\"readable bookTitle\" href=\"https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/22750124-stories-of-the-raksura-volume-2?from_choice=false&amp;from_home_module=false\">Stories of the Raksura, Volume 2: The Dead City &amp; The Dark Earth Below<\/a><\/h2>\n\n      <div>\n        by <a class=\"authorName\" href=\"/author/show/87305.Martha_Wells?a=7&amp;origin=related_works\">Martha Wells<\/a><span title=\"Goodreads Author!\">*<\/span>\n      <\/div>\n\n          <div class=\"smallText uitext darkGreyText\">\n            <span class=\"minirating\"><span class=\"stars staticStars\"><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p10\"><\/span><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p10\"><\/span><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p10\"><\/span><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p10\"><\/span><span size=\"12x12\" class=\"staticStar p3\"><\/span><\/span> 4.29 avg rating &mdash; 638 ratings<\/span>            &mdash; published 2015\n          <\/div>\n\n    <div class=\"addBookTipDescription\">\n      \n<span id=\"freeTextContainer5686500079019762573\">Moon, Jade, and other favorites from the Indigo Cloud Court return with two new novellas from Martha Wells.Martha Wells continues to enthusiastically ignore genre conventions in her exploration of the fascinating world of the Raksura. Her novellas an<\/span>\n  <span id=\"freeText5686500079019762573\" style=\"display:none\">Moon, Jade, and other favorites from the Indigo Cloud Court return with two new novellas from Martha Wells.Martha Wells continues to enthusiastically ignore genre conventions in her exploration of the fascinating world of the Raksura. Her novellas and short stories contain all the elements fans have come to love from the Raksura books: courtly intrigue and politics, unfolding mysteries that reveal an increasingly strange wider world, and threats both mundane and magical.“The Dead City” is a tale of Moon before he came to the Indigo Court. As Moon is fleeing the ruins of Saraseil, a groundling city destroyed by the Fell, he flies right into another potential disaster when a friendly caravanserai finds itself under attack by a strange force. In “The Dark Earth Below,” Moon and Jade face their biggest adventure yet; their first clutch. But even as Moon tries to prepare for impending fatherhood, members of the Kek village in the colony tree’s roots go missing, and searching for them only leads to more mysteries as the court is stalked by an unknown enemy.Stories of Moon and the shape changers of Raksura have delighted readers for years. This world is a dangerous place full of strange mysteries, where the future can never be taken for granted and must always be fought for with wits and ingenuity, and often tooth and claw. With these two new novellas, Martha Wells shows that the world of the Raksura has many more stories to tell…\n\nContains: \nThe Dead City #0.3\nMimesis #3.4\n Trading Lesson #3.5\n The Almost Last         });

      $('bookCover_18516130').observe('prototip:shown', function() {
        if (this.up('#box')) {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });

      newTip['wrapper'].addClassName('prototipAllowOverflow');

        $('bookCover_18516130').observe('prototip:shown', function () {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function (e) {
            if ($('bookCover_18516130').hasClassName('ignored')) {
              e.setStyle({'display': 'none'});
              return;
            }
            e.setStyle({'overflow': 'visible'});
          });
        });
      $('bookCover_18516130').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

Frank Baum introduced Dorothy and friends to the American public in 1900, The Wonderful Wizard of Oz became an instant, bestselling hit. Today the whimsical tale remains a cultural phenomenon that continues to spawn wildly popular books, movies, and musicals. Now, editors John Joseph Adams and Douglas Cohen have brought together leading fantasy writers such as Orson Scott Card and Seanan McGuire to create the ultimate anthology for Oz fans—and, really, any reader with an appetite for richly imagined worlds. \n\nStories include: Seanan McGuire’s “Emeralds to Emeralds, Dust to Dust” finds Dorothy grown up, bitter, and still living in Oz. And she has a murder to solve—assuming Ozma will stop interfering with her life long enough to let her do her job. In “Blown Away,” Jane Yolen asks: What if Toto was dead and stuffed, Ozma was a circus freak, and everything you thought you knew as Oz was really right here in Kansas? “The Cobbler of Oz” by Jonathan Maberry explores a Winged Monkey with wings too small to let her fly. Her only chance to change that rests with the Silver Slippers. In Tad Williams’s futuristic “The Boy Detective of Oz,” Orlando investigates the corrupt Oz simulation of the Otherland network. Frank Baum’s son has the real experiences that his father later fictionalized in Orson Scott Card’s “Off to See the Emperor.”\n\nSome stories are dystopian... Some are dreamlike...           $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});
        } else {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});
        }
      });

      newTip['wrapper'].addClassName('prototipAllowOverflow');

        $('bookCover_16108066').observe('prototip:shown', function () {
          $$('div.prototip').each(function (e) {
            if ($('bookCover_16108066').hasClassName('ignored')) {
              e.setStyle({'display': 'none'});
              return;
            }
            e.setStyle({'overflow': 'visible'});
          });
        });
      $('bookCover_16108066').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {
        $$('span.elementTwo').each(function (e) {
          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {
            var lessLink = e.next();
            swapContent(lessLink);
          }
        });
      });

</script>

The captain doesn’t quite know what to do with Lisbet, but he can’t let her die alone in space. He orders his men to tow her life pod into their battle ship.\n\nVal is the last of his line – heir to a doomed legacy – because no respectable jit\'suku woman will have him after the destruction of his family. He has put all his considerable resources into building his state-of-the-art battleship and joining the fight to take the human galaxy, hoping to restore his honor in some small way. This is Val’s first foray into human space and his first encounter with a human female. He finds her strangely alluring and altogether irresistible.\n\nLisbet is attracted to Val as well. When he puts the moves on her, she can’t resist his masculine charm, but she doesn’t like being a prisoner – even if she is being kept in a gilded cage, treated more like a guest. She doesn’t know a lot about jit’suku culture and it’s pretty clear they don’t understand much about humans.       <div id="aboutAuthor" class=" clearFloats bigBox"><div class="h2Container gradientHeaderContainer"><h2 class="brownBackground"><a href="/author/show/1967.Tanya_Huff">About Tanya Huff</a></h2></div><div class="bigBoxBody"><div class="bigBoxContent containerWithHeaderContent">
          <div class='bookAuthorProfile'>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__topContainer'>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__photoContainer'>
<a href="/author/show/1967.Tanya_Huff"><div class='bookAuthorProfile__photo' style='background-image: url(https://images.gr-assets.com/authors/1207242126p3/1967.jpg);'></div>
</a></div>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__widgetContainer'>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__name'>
<a href="/author/show/1967.Tanya_Huff">Tanya Huff
</a></div>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__followerCount'>
1,869
followers
</div>

</div>
</div>
<div class='bookAuthorProfile__about'>

<span id="freeTextContainer18202320789834740549">"Born in Halifax, Nova Scotia: Although I haven't actually lived "down east" since just before my fourth birthday, I still consider myself a Maritimer. I think it's something to do with being born in sight of the ocean. Or possibly with the fact that almost no one admits to being from Ontario…<br /><br />Raised, for the most part, in Kingston, Ontario. It was the late sixties, early to mid seventies. Enough s</span>
  <span id="freeText18202320789834740549" style="display:none">"Born in Halifax, Nova Scotia: Although I haven't actually lived "down east" since just before my fourth birthday, I still consider myself a Maritimer. I think it's something to do with being born in sight of the ocean. Or possibly with the fact that almost no one admits to being from Ontario…<br /><br />Raised, for the most part, in Kingston, Ontario. It was the late sixties, early to mid seventies. Enough said for those of us who lived through it-and those who didn't seem to be getting another chance to fall off platform shoes.<br /><br />Spent three years in the Canadian Naval Reserve: I was a cook. They'd just opened it up to women and I figured it would be the first trade that would send women to sea. I was right. Unfortunately it happened a year after I left. No tattoos.<br /><br />Received a degree in RADIO AND TELEVISION ARTS (B.A.A.) from Ryerson Polytechnical Institute: The year I graduated was the year that the CBC laid off 750 employees in Toronto alone. We were competing for jobs with people who had up to five years experience. The cat threw up on my degree.<br /><br />Spent eight years working at Bakka, North America's oldest surviving science fiction book store: Change Of Hobbit in California was actually a very little bit older but unfortunately it was a casualty of the recession in '91. During those eight years, while working full-time, I wrote seven books (the first seven, except for the original draft of CHILD), and nine short stories.<br /><br />In 1992, after living in downtown Toronto, a city of nearly three million, for thirteen years, I moved with two large cats, one small psychotic cat, and my partner out to a rented house in the middle of nowhere. In the years since, we've purchased the house, buried two of the original cats, replaced them with three more felines and, unintentionally, acquired a Chihuahua. You're probably wondering how two reasonably intelligent adults can unintentionally acquire a Chihuahua. Please don't ask.<br /><br />I love living in the country, writing full-time, anything by Charles de Lint, Xena, Hercules, and email. I dislike telephones, electric blankets, and bathroom renovations.<br /><br />I always expect catastrophe; as a result, I'm usually pleasantly surprised."<br /><br />Huff lives with her wife, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/69803.Fiona_Patton" rel="nofollow">Fiona Patton</a>.</span>
  <a data-text-id="18202320789834740549" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>

</div>
</div>

<div class="clear"></div></div></div><div class="bigBoxBottom"></div></div>
